column1: The Challenge also employs a multi-faceted managerial strategy that envisions itself as hands-on catalyst for directing and ensuring that the work of watershed restoration gets completed in accordance with the cooperative conservation mission. The components of the strategy include:
• the presence of the BC’s hands-on board of directors
• the recruitment of “focal” people
• the long-term perspective provided by the mission in combination with a selective partnering approach
• the embrace of staffing changes to fit the different stages of BC growth
• a core catalyst model of minimalist bureaucracy
column2: and

column1: • a commitment to transparency and accountability to others. (see Weber 2012 for full development of these points)
Finally
column2: the Challenge takes a conservative
column3: patient approach to the projects and programs they do fund.  The basic rule is “don’t do it unless all the funding in place” (Personal Interview
column4: 2008). Such an approach lengthens the calendar and slows progress
column5: while simultaneously reducing the risk of incompletion and failure
column6: this helping the BC to bolster their reputation for getting things done and getting them done successfully.

column1: Programmatic Successes:

Has established and managed over 100 programs and projects. The following programs and outcomes are indicative of the kind and range of work that has earned the collaborative national recognition and a series of national performance awards.
Comprehensive Conservation Easements. Starting in 1995
column2: the BC and one of its primary partners
column3: the USFWS
column4: has secured conservation easement coverage on 90
column5: 000 acres involving 65 private landowners and 75 easements. These are innovative
column6: comprehensive approach co-developed in 1995 by the BC and USFWS that addresses all parts of a landscape as well as development pressures.

column1: Water Conservation and Drought Management. in drought years over 70 Blackfoot River irrigators and water users share the pain of low water flows by voluntarily donating 60 cubic feet per second (cfs) to instream flows. Science shows that 60 cfs keeps water temperatures cold enough to support healthy trout populations and other key biota. Under the “Shared Sacrifice” program rights holders do not lose their rights for lack of use because is a beneficial use under state water law. To help
column2: BC installed 15 in-ground soil moisture monitors to assist in better managing required water flows for crops/livestock. The result--every year but one since the program started in 2003
column3: the Blackfoot River has met or exceeded the 60 cfs minimum. Also fishing bans during hot weather/low water.

column1: Riparian Habitat
column2: Streams
column3: Water Quality Restoration. BC engaged 147 landowners and 500 projects in areas of highest ecological value. Restored flows to natural channels on 38 miles of streams on 41 tributaries and 62 miles of riparian areas out of a total 1
column4: 900 miles of perennial streams capable of supporting fisheries. Removed more than 460 miles of fish passage barriers
column5: installed thirteen fish screens to prevent fish from getting into irrigation canals
column6: and restored 2
column7: 600 acres of wetlands. Five Water Quality Restoration Plans (TMDL Plans) have been approved by EPA; off stream stock watering helps streamside plants grow
column8: providing shade to cool water.

column1: The Blackfoot Community Forest Project. A comprehensive effort to restore the ecological and biological integrity of 88
column2: 000 forest acres. Purchased private land from Plum Creek Timber
column3: deeded it over to USFS
column4: and created a public forest jointly owned and managed by community stakeholders.

column1: Endangered Species and Wildlife Conservation. • Human-grizzly bear conflicts reduced by 67% since 2001 despite large increases in sightings and recolonization; 5% annual increases in elk population; reversed trumpeter swan decline; Cutthroat trout populations increased 10-fold by 2004; bull trout redds increased 5-fold in 2 streams by 2004
Noxious weeds. Engaged 380 landowners
column2: utilizing integrated weed management practices on 45
column3: 000 acres of noxious weeds in 11 different management zones.

column1: Change over time is acceleration and massive growth of problem solving capacity and program implementation.

Island Press. http://seas.umich.edu/ecomgt/pubs/crmp/clarkcounty.PDF;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;North America;Select;Select ;Select ;Select ;Off;Off;Off;Off;On;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;;5;5;5;5;5;5;Off;Off;Off;1;3;5;Off;1;3;3;Off;1;3;3;Off;1;3;5;Off;1;1;1;Off;1;1;1;Off;;Off;Off;Off;Off;1;5;5;1;5;5;1;1;1;1;1;1;Off;Off;Off;Mostly confident;In 1989
column2: as the result of a court case brought by environmental groups
column3: the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service ""listed"" the Desert Tortoise as an endangered species.  The critical implication of this listing is that desert tortoise habit could not be disturbed.   Since the city of Las Vegas is smack-dab in the the middle of prime Desert Tortoise habitat
column4: this listing had the potential effect of halting development in what was one of the fastest growing cities in the U.S. at the time.  The U.S. Endangered Species Act does
column5: however
column6: provide an option for local stakeholders to come together to develop a ""habitat conservation plan"" for protection of a species while allowing habitat use.   Clark County
column7: a county government with a very large geographic jurisdiction that includes the city of Las Vegas
column8: took the lead on convening this habitat conservation planning process.   The process required bringing developers
column9: ranchers
column10: mining interests
column11: environmental groups and a range of local
column12: state and federal agencies together to collaboratively design a habit conservation plan.   Thus
column13: the main goal of the planning process was to create a solution (a plan) that would protect the desert tortoise while allowing some further land development.   An important point is that much of the land in Clark County is Federal public land.

column1: NOTE: In the answers above and below
column2: I treat the ""start of the period"" as the period from the listing of the Desert Tortoise to the initiation of the habitat conservation planning process.   I treat the ""middle of the observed period"" as the early-mid period of the collaborative process when the stakeholders first forged a working process.   I treat the ""end of the period"" as the late period of the initial collaboration before it transitioned to the ""multi-species habitat conservation planning process.""

column1: The process began on a very sour note because of the adversarial legal relations between the parties
column2: but the stakeholders eventually developed a modus vivendi and crafted a plan that preserved high value tortoise habitat and allowed development on less valuable habitat (thus
column3: it became concerned about the ""effectiveness"" of interventions to protect the tortoise; the flip-side was a concern to develop an ""efficient"" system of protection that did not prevent valuable development).   As the process developed
column4: it required the collaborative process to ensure the legitimacy of the plan to various stakeholders
column5: since all parties had to support the final plan (only the ranchers defected and then lost their court case).  As they worked through the process
column6: the stakeholders also become aware of the potentially innovative nature of the planning technique and eventually they extended the process into a full-blown ""multi-species"" planning process.";3;1;Self-initiated by participants;2;3;Off;4;4;4;4;3;4;Off;Off;5;Reasonably confident;"The process started off in a very adversarial way.  Recall that the environmentalists had taken the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to court to force it to list the Desert Tortoise as an endangered species and further court cases followed to try to stop the listing (but these failed).   So the major stakeholders were very antagonistic towards one another and highly distrustful.   As noted above
column7: the collaboration was initiated by Clark County Government under the habitat conservation planning proviso of the Endangered Species Act.   This process was not mandated
column8: but the law gave Clark County the possibility to construct a collaborative planning process. At the same time
column9: I would not describe this process as ""self-organized"" by stakeholders
column10: since they evidenced little inclination to work together.  In other words
column11: the leadership of Clark County was critical.  However
column12: the developers did have a very strong incentive to come to the bargaining table
column13: because otherwise further urban development would have been halted (an economically disastrous and probably unthinkable outcome from their point of view).   It is somewhat harder to understand the incentives for the environmentalists to come to the table
column14: since the listing had basically halted all development. My best guess in this case is that they thought that a collaborative strategy would be better for preserving the Desert Tortoise in the long run.  Otherwise
column15: it could get mired down in court with developers and other stakeholders adopting different legal and political strategms for going around the Endangered Species Act.   A very great deal was at stake for the city of Las Vegas
column16: the state of Nevada and for the powerful developers.   There is also a difference between ""halting development"" and taking more positive steps toward protecting habitat.  There was arguably some differences in power and resources between the environmentalists and developers.  However
column17: the more significant power asymmetry was between these stakeholders and a group of geographically dispersed and unorganized stakeholders (individual miners
column18: off-road ethusiasts
column19: small landowners).   Since they were individuals scattered around a wide geographical region (Clark County is huge)
column20: it would have been almost impossible for them to regularly attend planning meetings.   Clark County reduced this asymmetry by hiring a lawyer o represent these more dispersed interests.";6-okt;6-okt;6-okt;Off;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;1;3;Off;3;1;3;3;Off;2;5;5;5;5;Off;5;Off;Mostly confident;"The first facilitator set out three ground rules:

column1: 1) No discussion about the validity of the Endangered Species Act
2) No debate over the listing of the tortoise
3) Everyone has to give up something
These rules are basically guidelines for ""bracketing"" the debate in order reduce tangential conflict and steer the process towards being constructive.   Other than these general ground rules
column2: there were not many formal ground rules about iinteraction.   But there were strong norms of interaction (consensus decisionmaking
column3: inclusiveness and transparency/openness).

column1: In addition to these ground rules
column2: the process established a steering committee
column3: a technical advisory committee
column4: and eventually an implementation & monitoring committee.   These committees helped to organize the work and keep the process moving forward.

column1: The interaction norms were consistently applied. The designers strongly emphasized the importance of inclusiveness.  The steering committee was quite large but very representative.   There was also a public participation component and the case studies describe meetings as large as 90 people.   The key ground rule was to be transparent in decisionmaking and to give everyone a chance to speak up.   Generally
column2: stakeholders felt like the collaborative process did a good job in giving everyone a right to speak and making stakeholders feel like it was an open and transparent process.   There was a also a norm of consensus decisionmaking.  Facilitators noted that the open
column3: inclusive and consensual approach was a key to its success
column4: but also note that you can never give stakeholders a chance to speak as much as they like
column5: nor can meetings be long enough to achieve perfect unanimity.   These design norms were present from beginning to end.   The one institutional design change that is observed over time is the frequency of meetings.  One facilitator notes that the collaborative would sometimes not meet for several months (because of shifting county priorities) and then meet a couple times a week for a few weeks.   Overall
column6: I feel like there were limited ground rules
column7: but that the norms of inclusiveness
column8: consensus decisionmaking
column9: and openness were strongly and consistently adhered to.

column1: The downside of inclusiveness
column2: consensus decisionmaking and openness was a lot of long
column3: exhausting meetings.";Off;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Off;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;3;5;5;Off;5;5;5;Off;5;5;5;Off;3;Off;3;3;Mostly confident;"As noted above
column4: Clark County took the lead in convening the process.  The process would not have gotten off the ground without the convening role of the County. However
column5: for the running of the meetings
column6: the County hired a faciliator who did a excellent job of mediating conflicts (mediator) and maintaining the integrity of the collaborative process (steward).  Skilled facilitation (especially mediation) was considered to be a key ingredient of the success of this collaboration.   One point made in the Aengst case document is that the skilled facilitation was responsible for keeping people at the table and one of the most remarkable aspects of this case was the high degree of stability of those who participated over a nine year planning period.

column1: Although a skilled facilitator led the meetings
column2: the creation of a steering committee implies a collective leadership.  The steering committee was composed of public organizations and private associations representing different interests.

column1: I have a harder time judging the ""catalyst"" role.   Certainly
column2: the process developed in a creative and innovative fashion.   However
column3: it is difficult to say from the case record whether the facilitator was critical for steering this creativity and innovation.   I would suspect the answer is yes
column4: but the case doesn't provide much guidance on this point.

column1: I see mostly consistency in leadership over time and don't see any major leadership shifts.   Perhaps it is worth emphasizing that there was a bifurcation in leadership roles.   The County Government was the lead actor and served as the convenor.  However
column2: it also hired a professional facilitator to conduct the meetings.  This was probably a good idea
column3: because the County was also a stakeholder in the process.

column1: ";1;3;4;Off;1;4;4;Off;5;1;3;Off;1;5;5;Off;1;3;5;Off;1;1;1;5;5;Off;Off;5;3;3;3;Off;Mostly confident;"As noted above
column2: the collaborative process began in an atmosphere of conflict and distrust
column3: but gradually developed into a constructive process.

column1: Early meetings had to have ""gun checks"" (this is the Wild Wild West!) and there was a sense of alienation.
Joint fact-finding missions were important early in the process.  Participants took field trips together to look at different tortoise habitats and this personalized the negotiation.
The communication process was ""face-to-face"" and very intense at times.

Shared knowledge formation was a critical part of the process.   A lot of the different agencies have different kinds of technical expertise and the capacity to conduct scientific studies. The importance of knowledge is indicated by the fact that there was a ""technical advisory committee (TAC).""   The overall process was led by a steering committee
column2: but there was also the TAC and eventually an implementation and monitoring committee.   At times
column3: there was also public participation in meetings.   So this was not a strongly centralized process
column4: but it did have some elements of central direction.

column1: The case materials make it pretty clear that over time and through face-to-face communication and personal interaction
column2: people developed respect for each other (despite ongoing conflict) and a sense of joint ownership over the process.   It is also clear that the process gradually built trust that was essential for fruitful compromise.";2;3;5;Off;2;3;5;Off;1;1;1;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Yes;3;4;2;2;3;3;1;2;2;1;2;2;Off;Off;Off;Off;Not very confident;"I felt like this was hardest set of questions to answer given what I know about the case.   The Clark County Board of Commissioners (elected) provided critical early leadership in convening the collaboration and provided important financial support.   However
column3: the collaboration itself included agencies and non-profit groups.  Individuals participated to some degree
column4: but I would say this was a process more driven by organized stakeholders than by independent citizens.   However
column5: Clark County did hire a lawyer to represent the more dispersed and unorganized (rural) citizens.   The collaboration did take seriously the need to gain external input from citizens
column6: but the core of the negotiating was done by 25-30 representatives of different organized interests.

column1: The overarching goal was to find a workable solution to the tradeoff between environmental protection and economic development.   The law itself provided some of the framework and defined some aspects of the habitat planning process.   However
column2: I would say that the goals got specified over time in an emergent fashion.   Ultimately
column3: the process produced a detailed habitat plan.

column1: The relationship to the Clark County Board of Commissioners continued throughout the collaboration because the County provided funding.   The collaborative therefore periodically explained itself to the commissioners in the context of making requests for funding.
Courts had indirect influence over the proceedings in the sense that legal dispute was the ""sword of damocles""--participants saw the collaborative process as preferable to going back to court.
Many of the agencies involved had regulatory functions and I am sure that local field office personnel had to explain the collaborative decisionmaking to higher level agency officials.  However
column2: the case materials focus more on what is happening in the collaborative process than what is happening outside of it.    In addition
column3: the process took place within the framework of Endangered Species regulation.   However
column4: the purpose  of the habitat planning process is to allow groups to come up with their own plans
column5: so this was not a case of direct regulatory control.

column1: Since much of the issue ended up focusing on preservation of tortoise habitat on public lands
column2: and in particular
column3: Bureau of Land Management land
column4: the whole process was subject to the legal and regulatory frameworks of federal resource agencies.

column1: I don't see much evidence of changing dynamics as the collaboration progressed.   As noted earlier
column2: the high degree of stability of participation by stakeholders (including state and federal agencies with regulatory functions) was one of the prominent features of the collaboration.

column1: ";1;3;5;Off;1;3;5;Off;1;3;5;Off;1;3;5;Off;1;3;Off;5;Off;1;3;5;Off;1;1;1;Off;1;3;5;Off;;Off;Off;Off;Off;1;3;5;1;3;5;1;1;3;1;1;3;Off;Off;Off;Off;1;3;3;1;1;1;1;3;5;Off;Off;Off;1;3;5;1;3;5;1;2;2;1;Off;1;1;Off;Off;Off;1;3;5;1;3;5;Off;Off;Off;1;3;5;Off;1;3;5;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Reasonably confident;"The immediate outcome of the process was a habitat conservation plan that protected critical Desert Tortoise habitat.

column3: 000 acres had already been protected and the plan ultimately protected 800
column4: 000 to 1 million acres (Beatley; Hoben).

column1: Millions of dollars in ""mitigation fees"" were also collected to support this habitat conservation ($550/acre was charged to developers and this money was then used to purchase prime tortoise habit and to support other preservation activities).
Much useful science about the desert tortoise was produced (there was a high degree of scientific uncertainty at the outset; research filled in some of the holes
column2: though certainty was of course never--and probably could never--be achieved).

column1: Other mitigation strategies were developed beyond land preservation.
Perhaps the most remarkable outcome of this collaborative planning process is that it transitioned into a ""multi-species"" planning process.    Basically
column2: the success of the Desert Tortoise process convinced the stakeholders that they could work together in this fashion to produce ""win-win"" outcomes.    Thus
column3: the process continued several more years after the Desert Tortoise plan was finished.

column1: An implementation & monitoring committee was also created to follow through on the implementation of the plan and monitor the results.
The basic pattern I see is that the stakeholders began the process incapable of working together effectively.   Through the collaborative process
column2: they began to develop effective working relationship and momentum built for a more ambitious strategy over time (from a plan for a single species to a multi-species plan).    Thus
column3: I often found myself coding a ""1"" in the initial period
column4: a ""3"" in the middle period
column5: and a ""5"" in the final period in order to convey the momentum that developed over time.

column1: CG_Case_Hermansson_20190815NewformatHH.pdf;Search and Rescue operations following the 2011 Van and Ercis (Turkey) earthquak;Helena Hermansson;Swedish Defense University;helena.hermansson@fhs.se;October;2009;Select;Select;May;November;2009;2015;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;;http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/0095399716680058;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Europe;Select;Turkey;Select ;Select ;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;On;Off;Off;On;disaster response;3;3;4;2;1;3;Off;Off;Off;1;1;1;Off;2;3;4;Off;3;5;5;Off;2;3;4;Off;5;5;5;Off;1;1;1;Off;;Off;Off;Off;Off;2;3;4;2;2;2;4;4;4;1;1;1;Off;Off;Off;Not very confident;"(1) Following a big earthquake in 1999
column2: it became clear that the state did not have sufficient resources for SAR and the state received massive critique for not coming to the rescue. At the same time
column3: NGOs active in SAR really came to the rescue and saved many more than the state authorities did. The response to this earthquake really set the stage for NGOs involvement in disaster management in Turkey. The state authorities also realize that they can't employ and keep enough cadres of professional SAR staff who sit and wait for an earthquake. Like an NGO representative said
column4: ""if it is normal day
column5: they have 100 SAR staff
column6: it is a disaster
column7: they have 100 SAR staff. For us
column8: if it is a normal day
column9: we are 1
column10: if it is a disaster
column11: we are 5000"".

column1: (2) The stated ambition on behalf of the national state authority responsible for SAR is to attain interoperability with SAR NGOs and improve collaboration. The stated ambition on the regional state authority level is to improve collaboration by increasing trust though joint exercises and education. The stated ambition on behalf of the NGOs is to be able to save more lives
column2: which they (mostly) have a better chance to do if collaborating with the state as it provides them with access to more resources and finances and also may speed up their operations (for example when the state flew them to the disaster area).

column1: (3) After the 1999 earthquake
column2: the Turkish disaster management system was reformed. A new agency (AFAD) charged with responsibility for all matters pertaining to disasters was created in 2009. Since the creation of AFAD there has been an increased focus on working with various NGOs
column3: among others SAR NGOs. The NGOs interviewed noticed a difference in outreach and interest on behalf of the state since the creation of AFAD
column4: since then
column5: steps toward collaboration have been more tangible. AFAD for example arranges joint workshops
column6: trainings and meetings and there has also been collaboration in SAR activities in the big cities during non-disaster times. AFAD has also strived to professionalize their SAR staff and aspire to have their regional SAR teams INSARAG-certified (international UN-standard) and some of the teams have also reached this goal.

column1: The increased interactions between AFAD and the SAR NGOs has resulted in mutual trust and smooth working relationships and role assignment is clear. This was also seen in the case of Van and Ercis. The NGOs I interviewed had no problems to be coordinated by AFAD while they also have a highly professional organization internally which means that they also can manage and coordinate their resources on their own if needed. During the Van and Ercis earthquakes the AFAD coordinated SAR NGOs from several cities and let them on the state's chartered planes to the area struck. On site
column2: the SAR collaboration with AFAD and SAR NGOs was well-functioning according to many of those involved
column3: both those directly in the collaboration
column4: but also according to actors working in other parts of the disaster response operations.

column1: ";Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Off;Yes;Off;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Yes;4;Off;3;2;Reasonably confident;"(1) It seems that SAR team leaders (operational) within AFAD
column2: which is with whom the SAR NGOs mainly interact in trainings and workshops
column3: had a facilitative leadership style that focused on building relations with SAR NGOs. I got the impression that this leadership was collegial and not bureaucratic or hierarchical. The bureaucrats and policy makers at AFAD in Ankara however seemed to have another attitude

column1: (2) Some SAR NGO actors are impressed with the initiatives taken by AFAD early on and appreciate that they really reach out to SAR NGOs
column2: which very rarely happened before when the Directorate of Civil Defense were in charge of SAR. (This is a general tendency
column3: AFAD strategy documents now list NGOs as strategic solution partners next to giants like the Ministry of Defense.) During the earthquakes
column4: some NGOs had troubles getting access and accreditation and felt directed and like they could only work in certain areas (politically motivated) but the SAR NGOs that had built trusting relationships with AFAD had no such problems. SAR NGOs also easily accepted working under the authority of AFAD

column1: Some of the more experienced SAR NGOs also know how to operate so as not to ""upset"" AFAD leadership. ""You have to be very careful as an NGO to not step on them
column2: or you know
column3: to try to take the leadership in these occasions"". The situation described was a collaborative search mission with AFAD
column4: where the actors from the SAR NGO was more experienced than the AFAD staff present. But the SAR NGOs generally seem to know how to navigate to make to collaborative process run smoothly while also managing to rescue or assist individuals. One SAR NGO described how
column5: after the initial SAR operations were over
column6: they switched to delivering aid instead. In this task they were formally under the provincial governor's command. But in this case
column7: this NGO actively avoided collaboration with the provincial governorate's crisis coordination center to be able to deliver aid more effectively. The SAR NGO team leader said that ""sometimes it is better to not push aside the government
column8: but if there is an immediate need
column9: I don't want to wait for five or six days for everything to get settled"".

column1: (3) Following the earthquake
column2: the Ministry of Interior released a report (of an evaluative character) that among other things stated that SAR capacity had improved immensely since the earthquakes in 1999. It however also stated that AFAD's SAR teams outperformed  the NGOs' SAR teams. When asking interviewees about this many were in agreement that this was not really true but that the state ""had to"" write like that. Such statements combined with AFAD bureaucrats' obsession with standards and paperwork have dampened the spirits with some SAR NGOs. column13: 389-406. Evaluation Dutch counterterrorism strategy 2011-2015 / Evaluatie van de nationale contraterrorisme-strategie 2011-2015.;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Europe;Select;Netherlands;Select ;Select ;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;On;On;On;Off;Off;;4;4;4;1;1;1;Off;Off;Off;3;3;4;Off;1;1;1;Off;5;5;5;Off;3;4;5;Off;5;5;5;Off;3;4;4;Off;;Off;Off;Off;Off;4;4;4;5;5;5;5;5;5;2;2;2;Off;Off;Off;Highly confident;"The Joint Committee for Counterterrorism brings together leading civil servants of all the national ministries and agencies involved with fighting violent extremism. This includes directors or deputy directors from the ministries of Justice
column14: Defense
column15: Social Affairs
column16: Health
column17: and Finance
column18: plus directors of the intelligences agencies
column19: police
column23: and other organizations. The Committee is chaired by the National Coordinator for Counterterrorism and Security
column24: a civil servant with his own relatively small agency to support him.

column1: The Committee is tasked with supporting the minister of Justice in formulating and implementing policies to counter violent extremism and terrorism. The Committee is specifically responsible for ensuring cohesion between the policies of the different parts of government
column2: and between international
column3: national
column4: and local initiatives. The Dutch counterterrorism community strives for a Comprehensive Approach
column5: combining preventive
column6: repressive
column7: security
column8: and social cohesion measures to fight terrorism.

column1: For the period of 2011 to 2015
column2: the Committee was guided by a minister-approved National Counterterrorism Strategy
column3: which aimed to (a) prevent attacks
column4: (b) limit the impact of any attacks that do occur
column5: and (c) reduce the societal fear for attacks. This explicit strategy was formulated in 2011 on the basis of a previous evaluation of the counterterrorism field between 2001 and 2010
column6: which concluded the agencies lacked a cohesive framework. This extensive strategy contained details and priorities for fulfilling the overall aims of the Dutch counterterrorism policy. Priorities included improving information sharing
column7: increasing technological government capabilities
column8: and improving international collaborations in the fight against chemical and biological weapons.

column1: The Netherlands had seen a political assassination by a left-wing extremist in 2002 and attacks by a cell of Al-Qaeda in 2004. Since 2009
column2: the official threat level had remained at `minimal.' The strategy of 2011 was therefore written in a period of relative calm. However
column3: the societal context and threat level changed dramatically between 2011 and 2015. The rise of ISIS in Iraq and Syria drew radicalized Muslims from the Netherlands and raised the specter of new attacks. In 2013
column4: the Dutch intelligence agencies signaled that the Islamic terrorist threat had morphed from international
column5: vertically organized networks  -such as al-Qaeda- into locally emerging and horizontally organized `swarms' of individual threats. By the end of 2017 over 270 Dutch nationals had joined ISIS. Attacks across Western Europe from 2012 onwards
column6: although never in the Netherlands
column7: showed that this threat was very concrete.

column1: The evolving threat put pressure on the responsible ministries and agencies. In 2014
column2: the committee had to quickly formulate an Action Plan to present to parliament
column3: including preventive
column4: repressive
column5: security
column6: and social cohesion measures. The minister of Justice
column7: in collaboration with the minister of Social Affairs
column8: took public responsibility for the implementation of this action plan. The Committee also face the rise of societal tensions around the arrival of refugees from Syria
column9: raising the threat of right wing extremist violence or left wing extremist pro-refugee threats.";3;3;Externally directed by law or authority;2;2;Off;2;3;3;4;2;3;Off;Off;5;Mostly confident;"The Committee was formed in response to the wave of attacks at the beginning of the 21st century. The attacks of 9/11 but especially Madrid prompted many European countries to create explicit counterterrorist legislation and coordinative bodies. Although the Committee is formally rooted in a 2004 ministerial decree
column10: most of these organizations have longstanding relationships with each other across multiple domains. They work together on drugs trafficking
column11: emergency management
column12: or immigration control. The opinions of each other have therefore been formed by many different interactions.

column1: There were some significant divisions between these parties. A first distinction can be made between the security versus the social development focused partners. The police
column2: intelligence agencies
column3: and Home Office tended to focus on the security causes and implications for violent extremism. The ministry for Social Affairs
column4: Education
column5: and Health looked to more personal or social drivers
column6: and were also concerned with the wider impact of terrorist attacks on societal tensions and cohesion.

column1: Moreover
column2: there was an imbalance in the weight and attention given to specific issues. Preventive interventions
column3: such as adequate schooling and early social support for potentially radicalizing individuals were signaled as important in the 2011 strategy
column4: but did not to get the same weight as more repressive measures targeting identified terrorists or protecting potential targets. These imbalances tended to give the police and other security services the upper hand in the committee
column5: while the socially oriented partners
column6: such as the Ministry of Social Affairs and Education stopped participating in the meetings in the first years after 2011.

column1: With the launch of the 2011 strategy
column2: the security-oriented partners mainly focused on their joint activities in the security domain
column3: for example
column4: sharing more information and countering chemical threats. The overall strength of the committee was initially undermined by deep budget cuts across all agencies following the 2008 Global Financial Crisis. The ministry of Social Affairs lost its Social Polarization Unit
column5: the intelligence agency had to let go of a large number of experts
column6: and the National Police was preoccupied with a large internal reorganization.

column1: With the emergence of a clear threat from 2013 onwards
column2: the committee gained in importance and cohesion. The different agencies received extra funding to deal with the extra work
column3: the ministries of Social Affairs
column4: Education
column5: and Health became active members again
column6: and the partners started working more closely on their collective interventions. The Action Plan of 2014 was an explicit mix of both social and security focused measures
column7: combining preventive and repressive interventions.

column1: Based on specific projects and interventions targeting local ISIS recruiters or extremist cells
column2: the security and social partners discovered that their interventions had to be combined to be effective. For example
column3: the police force may detain a suspected ISIS recruiter
column4: but the social services need to then immediately reach out the pupils of the recruiter
column5: offering them jobs and housing to prevent them from further radicalizing. ";6-okt;6-okt;nov-15;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;4;4;Off;3;4;3;3;Off;2;4;3;3;4;Off;4;Off;Highly confident;"The ministerial decree founding the Committee provides minimal procedural rules
column6: merely specifying which organizations are members by default (all the security partners)
column7: which agencies may be invited (most government departments)
column8: that the National Coordinator staff acts as secretary
column9: and that the Committee must meet at least ten times a year. The Committee is also instructed to act in accordance with the relevant laws on policing
column10: information sharing
column11: and state secrets. Further procedures are purposefully not made public given the sensitive nature of the Committee work.

column1: In line with the relatively informal administrative culture of the Netherlands
column2: which often favors collaboration and committee rule over strict separations and hierarchy
column3: the Committee itself did not develop extensive protocols or procedures. The National Coordinator acted as chair and mediator
column4: rather than chief or monitor (see Leadership block). The meetings were structured in accordance with the business at hand and partners were invited to join the committee when deemed useful.

column1: The wider rules structuring the hierarchies and relationships between the agencies was in some cases very extensive. For example
column2: the police was placed under the command of both the minister of Justice and the Crown Prosecution
column3: just as Customs was ultimately answerable to the minister of Finance. The intelligence agencies were not allowed to indiscriminately share sensitive data with the prosecution
column4: as information gathered through intelligence instruments may not be easily admissible in court.

column1: In a pragmatic turn
column2: especially in times of pressure
column3: these rules were often tested and adjusted where possible. The partners created a separate unit where representatives of different organizations could quickly share data on individuals deemed to be a risk (a so-called Counterterrorism Infobox). If these professionals thought it necessary
column4: they could make a formal request for handing over data formally from one organization to the other.

column1: During the drafting of the 2014 Action Plan
column2: some cracks did appear in these inclusive and transparent rules. The minister of Justice promised parliament the quick delivery of a plan to counter so-call `Jihadism'
column3: sending the national coordinator in quick dash for collecting different proposals. Looking back on those frantic days
column4: several actors felt that they were not sufficiently involved
column5: especially civil servants representing the constitutional checks on investigative powers or partners representing the social cohesion perspective.";Off;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;4;3;4;Off;2;3;4;Off;2;3;4;Off;2;Off;3;4;Mostly confident;"The Netherlands opted specifically for a National Coordinator for Counterterrorism in 2004
column6: rather than appointing an overall director or `czar' for Homeland Security. The idea was that too many different agencies had to be involved in a counterterrorism strategy than could reasonably be amalgamated
column7: and that the Dutch administrative culture was not suited to a single director overruling other departments.

column1: In comparison to much older institutions such as the police or Crown Prosecution
column2: the Coordinator was a relatively new player. Most partners signaled their respect in interviews for the dedication and expertise of the Coordinator. The Coordinator himself and his staff were seen as committed to the shared outcomes of all the different partners and capable of quickly connecting different policy domains.

column1: The Coordinator was particularly active in connecting individual interventions and providing backup capacity. The Action Plan was used by the Coordinator to combine all the separate powers and activities of different agencies into one unified response. During this first crisis time
column2: the Coordinator staff would also provide knowledge and manpower to the police
column3: local government
column4: social welfare agencies which lacked either knowledge about violent extremism or capacity to act. Some criticism from the police
column5: prosecution
column6: and intelligence agencies was then be that the Coordinator was taking over their role
column7: although all parties admitted such minor turf wars are to be expected in collaborations.

column1: The Coordinator did face more serious criticism from the partners in that he himself and his agency were too close to the minister
column2: acting as an political enforcer rather than a neutral broker. Especially as the pressure rose after 2013
column3: the Coordinator took responsibility for making sure that agreed upon measures were quickly implemented and were reported to parliament. The executive agencies felt that the politicians and Coordinator were focusing too much on the quantitative results
column4: while most of the gains would be of a more qualitative nature.

column1: ";2;3;4;Off;3;3;3;Off;4;3;5;Off;3;4;5;Off;4;5;5;Off;3;3;2;5;5;Off;Off;5;4;5;3;Off;Mostly confident;"Despite the large group of different actors involved
column2: the relationships were usually personable
column3: cordial and constructive. The main divisions
column4: such as between the security and social cohesion actors
column5: did not manifest themselves  through open conflict
column6: but indirect attempts to mend the fences through bilateral conversations.

column1: The parties had to work together intensively to make solutions happen. This was true before the rise of ISIS
column2: where the agencies has work together to align their information systems and strategic priorities
column3: and even more so after the threat became apparent in 2013
column4: when parties had to closely operate in targeting specific threats.

column1: The strategy of 2011 provided a formalized vision of the desired collective outcomes. This vision was mainly written the National Coordinator staff
column2: acting act as mediator and broker between the different agencies. The shard vision was built through a range of bilateral and sometimes collective meetings about the strategy and specific operational priorities.

column1: Between 2011 and 2013
column2: most of the focus was on adjusting the threat level and executing the agreed plan
column3: with no real changes in the outlook of partners. In 2014
column4: the domestic intelligence agency published a memo detailing the shift from international terrorist networks to horizontally organized `swarms'. This new vision provided a new frame to understand the evolving threat and was quickly adopted by the different partners.

column1: The Action Plan of 2014 which was drafted in response to the changing circumstances came about rushed circumstances (see other sections). The Coordinator would organize collective sessions for all partners that could be available at short notice. The proposed actions were often recycled plans already desired by specific partners
column2: such as new passport control measures and extra data gathering capabilities. This process caused considerable friction between the parties
column3: especially between the constitutional camp and the security agencies.

column1: Over time partners came to appreciate the value and added benefits of bringing different perspectives to the table. The police
column2: for example
column3: became a strong advocate for more investment in social service in order to provide better services for individuals turned away from radicalization and towards social integration. Partners so started to purposefully integrate different perspectives in their policy proposals and actions plans to utilize their collective strength and create broad appeal
column4: although differences would still flare up regularly

column1: ";4;5;4;Off;4;5;4;Off;3;5;5;Off;2;4;4;2;2;2;Off;Off;2;4;4;Off;2;4;4;Off;2;2;4;4;2;2;2;2;2;2;2;2;Off;Off;Off;Off;Mostly confident;"The formulation of the first collective counterterrorist strategy in 2011 provided clear goals and more explicit accountability mechanisms. The different partners monitored each other's contributions to the execution of the strategy by collectively reviewing their progress in the Committee meetings. They were externally governed by laws on intelligence work and supervised by a select parliamentary committee on intelligence. When the strategy was published in 2011
column2: the minister also promised parliament a public evaluation in 2015. This evaluation was duly executed by independent academic researchers (see link provided).

column1: The Action Plan of 2014 contained even more explicit actions and measures
column2: with the ministers reporting progress to parliament every three months. A problem was that measures could be formally implemented
column3: i.e. a change in the law on dual nationality of terror suspects
column4: but the question was still how often the measure was used in practice and what the effects of the intervention were. Partners felt that a true measure of progress would rely on more qualitative insights in the ability of the partners to collaboratively counter different types of threats.

column1: Several oversights agencies were also involved in holding the collective agencies to account. Another evaluation commission reviewed the information sharing between the agencies about specific individuals (the aforementioned Counterterrorism InfoBox). The Court of Auditors published a review of the effect of the previous budget cuts on the intelligence agencies. The Inspectorate of Security reviewed the implementation of the different anti-radicalization policies at the local level.
The committee itself did not have an extensive public profile
column2: most of the advocacy groups and citizens committees would therefore direct their messages at the relevant politicians.. The civil servants at some of the organizations
column3: especially the ministries
column4: would work directly with societal groups to prepare proposals or build support. However
column5: due to subsidy cuts by previous government
column6: most of the collective representing Muslim minorities
column7: a group strongly affected by the policies
column8: had become defunct by 2013. The rising investment in executive agencies was however accompanied with new subsidies for such societal groups in 2014.

column1: ";3;4;5;Off;1;1;1;Off;4;5;4;Off;1;1;1;Off;4;4;Off;Off;Off;3;2;4;Off;4;4;4;Off;3;4;4;Off;;Off;Off;Off;Off;2;4;5;3;4;5;3;5;5;2;2;4;Off;Off;Off;Off;3;3;4;3;2;3;3;3;4;Off;Off;Off;2;4;5;2;4;5;2;3;4;4;Off;3;2;Off;Off;Off;2;3;4;2;3;3;3;4;4;2;3;3;Off;2;2;3;Off;Off;Off;Off;Reasonably confident;"Measuring the impact of counterterrorist work is extremely difficult. An absence of terrorist attacks is not a sign success; the policy efforts may have indeed prevented attacks
column2: but a country might have also gotten lucky. Any evaluation of the impact of this network
column3: especially an abstract look at outcomes
column4: needs to be very cautious and modest. We can observe that there were no formally recognized terrorist attacked in the years 2011 to 2015. However
column5: more than 20 mosques were attacked with fire bombs in this period
column6: but these were not treated as terrorist incidents by the police. Also
column7: etween 2012 and 2016 over 270 Dutch nationals joined ISIS.

column1: The collective agencies lost collective strength and capacity in the first years after 2011. The budget cuts and reorganizations severely affected the intelligence agencies and the police
column2: where the network also lost the engagement of the socially oriented partners. When ISIS started recruiting people
column3: the agencies and media reported several failed attempts to identify radicalizing individuals. In later years
column4: the agencies were more confident they had the knowledge
column5: resources
column6: and contacts to identify potentially radicalizing individuals.

column1: The innovative capacity of the Committee did therefore not lie in developing new services
column2: but finding simple yet effective ways to join their collective problem solving capacity. In the beginning
column3: the Committee achieved concrete innovative results in restructuring several of their processes
column4: such as streamlining information sharing
column5: improving threat analysis
column6: and limiting biological and chemical threats. After 2014
column7: the partners responded to the threat in 2014 with a series of fairly innovative local deradicalization programs
column8: where different cities would receive customized support in targeting specific groups in their locality. The lessons from the 2011-2015 period also led to a new approach to strategy formulation
column9: emphasizing collaboration and flexibility in the national strategy drafted for 2016-2020.

column1: The legitimacy of the Committee changed over the years. The Committee only had support from a narrow group of security agencies
column2: and did also not seek engagement or support from other partners. The first responses to the new ISIS threat were criticized for being too security focused
column3: ignoring the social aspect of radicalization
column4: and eroded support from minority groups and human rights organizations for the initial government response. The subsequent reconnection with the more socially focused partners
column5: allowed the Committee to tweak its messaging
column6: champion investment in the causes of radicalization
column7: and so broaden the support for the overall approach of counterterrorism.";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

CG_Case_Rubin_20190402.pdf;Collaborative governance in Vietnam flooding;Olivier Rubin;Department of Social Sciences and Business
column2: Roskilde University;rubin@ruc.dk;January;2011;Select;Select;January;September;2011;2016;Yes;Yes;Yes;Off;Yes;;https://brill.com/abstract/journals/ajss/43/6/article-p760_6.xmlhttps://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/apv.12037https://www.springer.com/la/book/9783642358036 ;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;East Asia;Select;Vietnam;Select ;Select ;Off;Off;Off;Off;On;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;On;;5;5;5;5;5;5;Off;Off;Off;2;2;2;Off;3;3;3;Off;3;3;3;Off;5;5;5;Off;3;3;3;Off;4;4;4;Off;;Off;Off;Off;Off;1;1;1;2;2;2;4;4;4;2;2;2;Off;Off;Off;Mostly confident;"The central Vietnamese government sought to collaborate with local associations and communes to provide disaster relief to vulnerable households in the wake of recurrent floods. Our research was primarily focused on central Vietnam
column3: but the findings appear to have a high degree of replicability to disaster management in Vietnam as a whole.

column1: Vietnam constitutes a special case not only because it provides an example collaborative governance in a developing country but also more importantly due to its distinct highly centralized political system. The central government is the highest organ of the governance system
column2: and it is controlled by the Communist Party of Vietnam (CPV). The CPV is the only legal party in Vietnam and its Central Committee is the top decision-making body. The local governance system in Vietnam is based on a three-tier system: the provincial level
column3: the district level and the commune (township) level. Local-level governments in Vietnam have a popularly elected council
column4: the People’s Council
column5: as well as an executive organ
column6: the People’s Committee. The People’s Council is the local organ of state power: it is accountable not only to the local citizens
column7: but also to the superior state organs. The People’s Committee
column8: on the other hand
column9: is the local organ of the state administration and is responsible for implementing the decisions made at the higher level. In addition to the councils and committees
column10: the local governments will also often have specialized agencies under the direct control of central line ministries. The key agency of relevance for flood relief is the Central Committee for Flood and Storm control.

column1: The governance collaboration between the central government and local communes/association was meant to reduce the adverse impact of flooding for rural vulnerable households. Flooding is the dominant natural hazard stress factor for vulnerable households in our research sites where 80% of the households categorised themselves as being highly vulnerable to floods. Relative to other stress factors (such as illness
column2: access to credit and access to land)
column3: flooding disasters were singled out in our survey as having the most serious impact on people’s livelihoods. People’s susceptibility to flooding was less caused by floods as such (most households are dependent on limited flooding for irrigation of their crops) but by flooding variability and severity. Households complained that traditional coping strategies
column4: such as elevated in-house storage facilities and conduits to protect against saturation
column5: were no longer sufficient protection against floods that they considered to be more severe
column6: faster (flash floods) and out of sync with the usual weather patterns (possibly because of climate change combined with the construction of hydropower plants and extensive deforestation). Thus
column7: many households were dependent on state relief to cope with floods. One of the few consistent findings in the disaster literature is the fact that the link between the vulnerable households and local governance is vital in a disaster situation. In situations where all community members face similar kinds of covariate risks
column8: the local government institutions can play an important role as a protector of the last resort. Concretely
column9: the emergency relief consisted mostly of rice
column10: noodles
column11: drinking water and a little cash.

column1: We did not observe any major changes to either issues or ambitions in the research period
column2: but it should be stressed that our research did not contain a substantial temporal component. While our anticipation was that an increased focus on participatory projects might impact the nature of collaborative governance
column3: it was noticeable how little impact they
column4: in fact
column5: had on the overarching centralized governance structure and processes.

column1: ;5;Off;Externally directed by law or authority;1;1;Off;4;4;1;4;5;5;Off;Off;5;Mostly confident;In terms of institutional responses to natural disasters
column2: the Central Committee for Flood and Storm control has been operational since 1955. The Ordinance on Flood and Storm Control in 1993 stipulates that at all levels throughout the country from central
column3: provincial to district and commune
column4: a Steering Committee for Flood and Storm Control shall be established. In emergency cases
column5: the Prime Minister and the chairmen of the People’s Committees of all levels may mobilize all forces
column6: supplies and means of any associations and individuals to rescue people
column7: projects and properties threatened or damaged by floods and storms and shall take responsibility for their decisions. Vietnam has compiled a National Strategy for Natural Disaster Prevention
column8: Response and Mitigation to 2020
column9: an Action Plan Framework for Adaptation and Mitigation of Climate Change in the Agriculture and Rural Development Sector and has adopted National Target Programmes in response to climate change. Multi stakeholders and community participants have been increasingly prioritised in the national target programmes. The 2010 World Development Report explicitly acknowledge that local communities typically precede national government in disaster response and adaptation
column10: and much research has documented the importance of local institutions in livelihood adaptation in the wake of disasters. Accordingly
column11: the Vietnamese government initiated several initiatives to improve local collaboration. At the time of our research
column12: the government allocated 1 trillion VND (appr. 45 million USD) projects aimed at raising community awareness in disaster risk management. Our research group was involved in a project on the local implementation of a participatory information system aimed to integrate and spatialize multi- and inter-disciplinary scientific and technological knowledge with indigenous experiences to improve the preparedness of the community.

column1: Historically
column2: the management structures clearly have build on authority and expertise that extend from the central level down to the provinces. The CPV was present in the lower governance tiers and dominated all aspects of flood preparedness. By this very structure
column3: interdependence between the actors – at the local and national level – was considerable as will be further substantiated in the next question. The incentives to cooperate
column4: however
column5: even for the local associations
column6: were determined by the central government. Thus
column7: the collaboration built on asymmetric power relations between the central government with the financial
column8: institutional and political resources and then the local communities.

column1: Again
column2: we did not observe any major changes over time in the research period. On the contrary
column3: the fundamental top-down governance structure in disaster management remained the same.

column1: ;20+;20+;20+;Off;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;3;3;Off;3;4;4;4;Off;Off;2;Off;2;Off;Yes;2;Off;Mostly confident;The ground rules of collaboration are dictated CPV through decrees and ordinances. There is no national law on food security or the right to food in Vietnam’s legislative framework. Vietnam does not have specific judicial procedures to deal with violations of rights to food
column2: and it does not have a separate
column3: independent institution to enforce rights to food in the country. Instead
column4: the government supplies food and other necessities in emergency cases at its discretion. In the absence of a rights-based approach
column5: such as rights to land
column6: livelihoods or food security
column7: rural people do not perceive of state support as other than situational endowments
column8: such as in emergencies after disasters. Thus
column9: the vulnerable households did not perceive disaster relief from the authorities as a right. The respondents expressed hope that they would receive immediate relief in the event of a disaster; they further hoped to receive some monetary compensation for the destruction caused by floods; and they hoped soon to be eligible for new and more disaster-resilient housing. However
column10: the immediate help during disasters (evacuation
column11: food
column12: shelter and water)
column13: as well as the rebuilding efforts (compensation and rebuilding of physical infrastructure)
column14: were clearly not rooted in ideas of state obligation and citizen’s rights.

column1: The Vietnamese collaborative approach to disaster management is top-driven
column2: with a clear focus on gauging the biophysical impacts of floods. Policies are mostly communicated down to the provincial government without clear plans and guidelines necessary to support implementation. There are clear vertical structures and hierarchies in the Vietnamese disaster management that confine and standardise initiatives along the more technocratic dimensions of the mainline ministries. Both the survey and additional interviews asserted that there is no encouragement for local people to organize spontaneously in order to carry out adaptation measures such as dikes
column3: pooling of resources
column4: protective forest belts
column5: joint house-building
column6: and the like. The local associations were not only dependent on the central government; they were an extension of the central government. This impacted the form of the collaborative governance. The governance structures tended to rely on command-and-control systems that resemble military operations and exclude participation; they sidelined local power structures and leave local people and institutions out of the community rebuilding process
column7: making recovery more difficult; and they ignored local people’s social and livelihood needs with the result that vulnerable groups may be left even more disadvantaged.

column1: Community collaboration outside the realm of the CPV associations and agencies was modest. Relatives and neighbours played a very marginal role in coping with floods. Formal organizing was weak
column2: while at the same time non-state actors were few and far between: ‘civil society’ development remains a sensitive issue. Neither traditional institutions such as Buddhist temples and lineage organization
column3: nor new civil society organizations have great rooms of manoeuvre in disaster management. They work closely with public authorities and in accordance with government programs as is the norm in Vietnam. Interestingly
column4: vulnerable households did not appear to pay much attention to the source of the disaster relief. Households were oblivious to whether the disaster relief they had received came from the state on one side or from domestic NGOs (for instance the Buddhist Associations) or international NGOs (for instance Oxfam and Red Cross) on the other. The fact that assistance from the state was not perceived to be qualitatively different from that of other sources is a direct consequence of most NGOs having to operate through state institutions.

column1: Again
column2: we did not observe any significant changes in the institutional architecture of collaboration over time.

column1: ;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;5;5;5;Off;2;2;2;Off;4;4;4;Off;1;Off;1;1;Mostly confident;As previously mentioned
column2: the style of leadership was very centre-driven. While reforms aimed at decentralisation and strengthening grassroots democracy have accelerated during the last decades
column3: the Vietnamese local governance system is still characterised by limited fiscal devolution
column4: as well as a lack of transparency and accountability. There was limited local authority autonomy. The central government continues to set tax rates and determine tax bases; the tax administration is still nationally centralised; and there continues to be heavy interference by central government in sub-national spending programmes. Central agencies keep control over the process of decision-making of local organs. The CPV strives to bring its governmental agencies as close as possible to the people and the villages in order to consolidate their organisational base. One of the chief means of rural consolidation and control is the Fatherland Front
column5: an umbrella group encompassing the many different CPV mass-associations including the Farmers’ Union
column6: Women’s Union
column7: the War Veterans’ Association and the Youth Unions. In this way
column8: the CPV stretches downwards through the government tiers into most aspects of rural organisation. Decentralisation in Vietnam has been interpreted as being more of an exercise of power than a devolution of power. The state administrative apparatus is interpenetrated by the Party apparatus at all levels of governance.

column1: Local associations are essentially political mass-organizations. Ninety-five percent of respondents in our study answered that members of their household were involved in formal associations. Only 6% reported being members of other organisations than the seven major mass-organisations tied to the CPV. These various formal mass-associations were increasingly being activated in preparing for floods. Interviewed members of the Farmers Union told us that they were part of village rescue teams
column2: and the Women’s Association had been involved in information dissemination and rescue teams when a major flood had occurred. These initiatives
column3: however
column4: were limited in scope and the active involvement (including training exercises) was restricted to a small portion of the surveyed/interviewed households. In addition
column5: all activities were undertaken in close collaboration with the local commune
column6: which functioned as an implementing agency. When asked about her greatest accomplishment in disaster management as head of the Women’s Association
column7: for instance
column8: the head replied that it was to get people to follow the government’s policies.

column1: The leadership
column2: in terms of initiative
column3: design and implementation
column4: primarily rested with the CPV. This produces a unique form of collaborative governance between the central government and local associations/communities during floods. From one perspective
column5: the governance is impressive when considering the reach and swiftness of the flood relief. The collaborative dimension of governance
column6: though
column7: is largely absent
column8: which results in subpar flood relief for many vulnerable households.

column1: We did not observe any fundamental changes over time.

;2;2;2;Off;5;5;5;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;2;2;2;Off;1;1;4;Off;4;2;4;2;4;Off;Off;1;4;2;4;Off;Mostly confident;An impressive rate of 93% of respondents reported receiving support from the local authorities during years when flooding struck. In-kind support (mainly clothes and food) was the predominant type of support received by 98% of those who got relief from the local authorities
column2: 30% received cash
column3: and less than 1% got a loan. Respondents were also asked to identify the most important sources of assistance when coping with natural disasters or other kinds of distress: 73% of the respondents pointed to relief from the local government
column4: while only 4% of the respondents identified neighbours as an important (not even the most important) source for disaster protection. In essence
column5: government relief is an essential part of coping strategies for vulnerable communities faced with recurrent floods. These statistics could surely be framed as an example of effective disaster governance. Surely
column6: the reach and the swiftness with which relief could be distrusted was impressive for a lower-middle income country such as Vietnam. The collaborative nature of this type of governance
column7: however
column8: was limited. Our empirical evidence indicated a limited role of the local community in the collaborative governance of disaster relief. While local authorities were indeed actively preparing for floods
column9: the nature of the collaboration was mainly restricted to act as subnational implementation units. Respondents referred to “announcements” as the single most important activity for the community associations. Announcements were almost exclusively conducted by loudspeakers while only a small minority of the respondents referred to announcements disseminated during community meetings where some participatory inputs could be gathered. Announcements are
column10: in general
column11: a top-down-driven form of communication and in the case of loudspeakers they are unequivocally also a one-way communication form. Only 2% of our respondents emphasized experience/information sharing as an activity in the collaboration with the government.  An overwhelming majority (more than 90%) described local meetings that could best be characterized as fora for state announcements and information dissemination. People were in their own words “reminded”
column12: “informed”
column13: “encouraged” and physically “moved”. Cumbersome administrative processes hampered any actual feedback. Suggestions needed to be in writing and pass through several bureaucratic layers. Such processes were beyond most vulnerable and unconnected households. The collaboration was mainly a mechanism for control and implementation rather than actual deliberation of policy.

column1: Accordingly
column2: key government agencies considered flooding an exogenous natural hazard that can be forecasted and then dealt with through dikes
column3: higher bridges
column4: water reservoirs
column5: and resilient infrastructure—what has been referred to as “climate proofing.” The remaining social problems are mainly dealt with through in-kind relief aid. With regard to the specific nature of disaster preparation
column6: a small minority (12%) of respondents emphasized disaster management initiatives that could be interpreted as rooted in civil society
column7: such as coordinating local meetings
column8: sharing best-practices
column9: streamlining village self-help groups
column10: and participating in community rescue plans. The vast majority of the respondents (62%)
column11: however
column12: emphasized state-led disaster policies
column13: such as the provision of better roads
column14: drainage
column15: dikes/dams and housing. The qualitative interviews also pointed to state-led preparatory activities that were mostly related to physical infrastructure
column16: such as preparing equipment
column17: stacking sand bags
column18: strengthening dikes and houses
column19: providing loans for safe-houses
column20: relocating people and deepening the waterways. The point here is not to denounce the importance of information dissemination or investments in physical infrastructure as part of an effective disaster management strategy. Rather
column21: it is to uncover the asymmetric collaborative nature of governance with respect to disaster response. The result was top-down preparatory efforts that emphasize the physical infrastructure side of disaster management
column22: with little involvement of the local communities.

column1: With respect to changes over time
column2: the centre-led collaborative governance process fundamentally remained the same despite an increased focus on participation and increased funding for community-led disaster management.";3;3;3;Off;2;2;2;Off;4;4;4;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Yes;2;5;5;5;2;2;2;2;2;1;1;1;Off;Off;Off;Off;Mostly confident;"In the Vietnamese case
column3: I feel this question will mostly be a repetition of my previous answers. Naturally
column4: this type of governance collaboration was limited in terms of electoral pressure
column5: NGOs and CSOs involvement
column6: oversight and accountability. The goals were formulated and monitored by the CPV. The state-led mass organizations had a near monopoly on rural organization
column7: and any voluntarism was channeled through these mass organizations. In fact
column8: households were often unaware of national policies and procedures related to disaster preparedness and planning: 49% of our respondents were unaware of national policies and procedures and 72% of interviewees did not know about disaster plans that were implemented at the community or commune level.  The strong bureaucracy
column9: top-down initiated policies and limited political accountability spurred a high degree of interaction with formal communities in disaster settings as well as high rates of memberships in political associations. However
column10: the nature of the collaboration inhibited community-led participation
column11: synergetic cooperation
column12: and risk sharing at the local level. Thus
column13: this type of collaborative governance might provide effective disaster relief through a quick and extensive mobilization of resources. But the disaster initiatives were not right-based and were not the result of bottom-up dialogue and stakeholder consultations. The interaction between local authorities and vulnerable households was substantial in quantitative terms. In qualitative terms
column14: however
column15: the close collaboration was not based on enforceable rights or electoral accountability. The result was disaster management that was mainly technocratic
column16: focused on climate proofing through the construction of dykes
column17: higher bridges
column18: water reservoirs
column19: resilient infrastructure and so on. The socio-economic disaster aid mostly consisted of short-term relief (food
column20: clothes and shelter) whereas longer-term aid to bolster resilience to the recurrent floods received less attention.

column1: Finally
column2: the template has been constructed with a liberal democratic government in mind. This is
column3: of course
column4: most obvious when the template mentions “elected politicians” but it also creeps up in some of the other overarching questions. This focus is obviously the right choice considering the sample of countries that you will include. However
column5: at times it made a bit difficulty for me to convey the true nature of the collaboration in the multiple choice questions. I hope these descriptions provides enough contextual information to allow you to interpret the template in the right way.

column1: ;4;4;4;Off;5;5;5;Off;1;1;1;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;3;3;3;Off;Off;4;4;4;Off;3;3;3;Off;4;5;4;Off;Cement existing power relations;5;5;5;Off;1;1;1;2;2;2;4;4;4;2;2;2;Off;Off;Off;Off;2;2;2;1;1;1;2;2;2;Off;Off;Off;2;2;2;3;3;3;2;2;2;4;Off;3;4;Off;Off;Off;4;4;4;5;5;5;3;3;3;4;4;4;Off;1;1;1;Off;Off;Off;Off;Mostly confident;The close-knitted collaboration between community and local authorities meant that the CPV could quickly identify and reach most flood victims.  Interestingly
column2: there is a significant positive relationship among the victims of floods between the importance placed on disaster relief from the local authorities on the one hand and then whether households received the disaster relief on the other. This could be indicative of good targeting in that those who deem state relief important are likely to receive it.   Both the objective indicators of disaster management (did you receive support and what kind?) and subjective indicators (rate the importance and usefulness of the support) point to a success in terms of disaster management. The outcomes
column3: therefore
column4: in terms of goal achievement and legitimacy can only be deemed high. However
column5: this type of collaboration is also indicative of a strong dependence on disaster relief from local authorities. The state-led mass organizations have a near-monopoly on rural organization
column6: and any voluntarism is channeled through these mass-organizations. Forms of collaboration are not formed by bottom-up processes of community self-organization and reaching out but through top-down processes where the state has annexed and institutionalized important civil society spaces. The relations of power and control over the collaborative processes are highly skewed in favor of the local authorities. This has implications for the collaborative network’s problem-solving capacity. Disaster management was primarily perceived as a technical issue. Disaster protection concentrated on reducing physically determined vulnerability with limited attention to the socially determined vulnerability. The social dimension was reduced to emergency aid (rice
column7: drinking water and shelter) while longer-term social policies
column8: catering to the specific needs of the communities
column9: were limited. Recall
column10: that less than one percent of the recipients of relief received loans. Community resilience
column11: thus
column12: did not increase over time.

column1: On the contrary
column2: in terms of ‘unintended’ consequences
column3: the state centered collaboration crowed out other forms of civil society
column4: bottom-up driven collaborations. Interviews with vulnerable households did not only indicate a substantial reliance on the local authorities for disaster protection
column5: but they also revealed a weak reliance on other forms of collaboration during floods. Relatives and neighbors appear to only play a very modest role in coping with disasters
column6: and more than 80 percent of the respondents rated aid from relatives and neighbors as irrelevant during disasters.  We did not find a single erected safe-house where the building had been cooperative effort between the villagers; what would have been equivalent to ‘barn raising.’ Even minor constructions such as higher ledges (to store food in-house) were a private matter. Simple communal collaboration efforts such as sharing of boats as a protection against major floods also did not appear to take place. The weak basis for civil society collaboration and the reliance on state support during and in the immediate aftermath of flooding leave very little scope for communal participation and local knowledge sharing. Vulnerable households risked being squeezed between the adverse consequences of the actual floods and then the centralized disaster management efforts that provided immediate relief but little in terms of longer-term community development and resilience building.
