It was estimated to affect almost one in four women in long-term relationships during their lifetime and each year since 2000
column2: Victoria Police had recorded more than 20
column3: 000 incidents. This
column4: according to experts
column5: was only the tip of the iceberg; research suggested that as many as 80 percent of cases went unreported. Family violence was one of the most confronting and complex aspects of police work. It was responsible for approximately 30 percent of police callouts; more than a third of those were repeat visits. When police were called out to an incident the approach police took was often superficial and focused on calming the immediate situation. Even though police had the capacity to take out intervention orders against offenders themselves
column6: there were legal hurdles and considerable paperwork; it wasn’t an option that was routinely pursued. Where offenders breached existing intervention orders
column7: they frequently weren’t investigated or prosecuted. Incidents were often considered in isolation
column8: without considering the history of the relationship or the needs of secondary victims such as children. The choice for victims of family violence was either to go to police “and get a fairly poor response”
column9: or to go to an NGA for usually short term support. Two pathways and two different systems meant women and children’s safety could easily fall into the gaps between.

column1: (2) In late 2001
column2: new Police Commissioner Christine Nixon announced three key areas she wanted to focus on: burglary
column3: motor vehicle theft and violence against women. She assigned an assistant commissioner (Leigh Gassner)  to the latter – specifically family violence and sexual assault who chose to first go and speak to community-based agencies before consulting widely within the police organisation. While Gassner was conducting these consultations
column4: he also approached the head of the Office of Women’s Policy about a joint effort to bring government and non-government agencies involved in family violence together. Through their respective Ministers the two government agencies then went to the Social Policy Committee of Cabinet and asked for two statewide steering committees to be formed: one on reduction of sexual assault; and the other on family violence. The Committee agreed to both and gave police and the Office of Women’s Policy the leadership role on the latter. The NGAs were keen to be involved. During mid-2002
column5: work began on the Statewide Steering Committee to Reduce Family Violence. The aim was to achieve a multi-agency and integrated response to the issue. (Meanwhile
column6: the police began work on producing a Victoria Police Code of Practice for investigating family violence.)

column1: (3) The first
column2: and in some respects the most difficult task was deciding how many participants to bring in and who they should be. There were literally hundreds of different service providers
column3: some with only four-figure grants and each with its own perspective. there was a lot of friction between the Department of Human Services (DHS) and the NGAs who were largely funded by DHS. The Department was also worried about NGAs driving the agenda. The Department of Justice was the other main government participant to join the Steering Committee
column4: along with the Departments of Human Services and Victorian Communities. As time went on participants on the Committee began documenting the problems and working on possible solutions in a report entitled: Reforming the Family Violence System in Victoria. The Steering Committee faced a setback when the Government declined the first funding application which disheartened members. But they were successful upon their second attempt.";2;2;Self-initiated by participants;1;1;Off;2;3;1;4;3;5;Off;Off;5;Highly confident;"Re (1) and (2)

column1: Additional information:
- The collaboration was initiated through the co-leadership of the new Police Commissioner

column1: -  The early stage of the Committee process  was about building relationships because there was a lot of mistrust from the service providers
column2: stemming from their deep sense of disappointment at years of police indifference (as well as from misunderstanding the nature and limits of police powers in this domain) and seeming lack of interest and/or funding clout from other government departments. The challenge was often around having government and NGAs on a committee which is trying to come together and co-design a model that it wanted to put forward to government. But some of those representatives were also service providers
column3: so they had a vested interest as well as wanting to get good outcomes for women and children. There initially was a lot uncertainty within the government agencies about they could work with the NGA's in a collaborative way without raising expectations that might not be met.

column5: grasping their intedependence and finding political/budgetary momentum to start working in a more holistic fashion.

column1: (2) The question of inclusiveness was a big one for this network. On the government side
column2: it was relatively
column3: both the justice/ law enforcement and human services/communities complexes needed to be represented. The question was at which level of seniority. Given that the setting up of the steering committee was directly authorized by the Victorian Cabinet
column4: and given the personal example and diplomacy of Christine Nixon
column5: the police commissioner
column6: the Committee ended up being composed of agency heads. Below that level

column10: and in some respects the most difficult task was deciding how many participants to bring in and who they should be. There were literally hundreds of different service providers
column11: some with only four-figure grants and each with its own perspective. NGAs were solving problems locally which meant that no two responses to women were the same. This approach would never address the widespread and brutal culture of family violence. The family violence sector has always thought that it was battling it out on its own. There were poor relations right across the board really reflecting a broken service system.” A/C Gassner recalls: “we tried to pick those peak bodies that could represent as much as possible the agencies that were on the ground dealing with family violence. It was hard because at a certain point we had to draw a line in the sand otherwise we would have needed the Rod Laver arena for meetings.” Nonetheless
column12: there were still many voices to be heard and reaching a common understanding of the issues was proving to be incredibly challenging.

column1: (3) Given these complexities and sensitivities
column2: procedural propriety and highly transparent processes were deemed essential. Gassner quickly realised that getting everyone to reach a common understanding was going to take longer than he thought. The two-hour monthly meetings soon extended to three. Said Gassner: “These issues involve so many disparate viewpoints and perspectives about how they should be handled and they’re all right to an extent but there was a need to bring them together. At

column1: meetings I used to forget the agenda because it just got to a point where I realised that certain discussions had never been had before. And I just had to let it run. Some of the people from government agencies were very personally affronted by what they were hearing but it needed to get out.” As time went on participants on the Committee began documenting the problems and
working on possible solutions in a report entitled: Reforming the Family Violence System in Victoria. Despite the growing connections and sense of common understanding
column2: preparing the document was still a long
column3: tortuous process.  NGAs were still struggling to enunciate their aims and principles and incorporate them in a model.

column1: (4) I have let the case terminate in mid 2006 when the steering committee was disbanded
column2: after its funding bid was successful and it was deemed that the newly engineered 'system' was now going to into an implementation phase. [what happened in the years thereafter could be a second case in its own right]. But for the duration of the current case period
column3: the governance structure and the suite of actors represented on it were stable. column1: (2) Gassner discovered that many agencies were working under false assumptions
column2: not only about what the police could do but what other services did. Gassner's low-key
column3: empathetic style proved crucial in him credibly performing the mediation role to all parties' satisfaction

column2: Cumberland took up a position with the Department of Victorian Communities and was confident that there was a whole-of government commitment to genuine improvement. While Victoria Police still occupied an important leadership position
column3: DVC had now taken a bigger role especially in coordinating the activities of larger government departments such as DHS and Justice. “The priority is the system
column4: that it is strong and that it will do what it says it will do so that women can have confidence in it
column5: ” said Cumberland. She acknowledged that it was difficult to operate a system across departments but felt they were making good progress: “When we check our thinking against Australian and international standards we are ahead in some areas and behind in others. But we are quite pleased with how we are travelling. The government has provided continuing vision and leadership
column6: knowing that we are seeking generational change.”

column1: Re (3): Two significant and strategically commissioned and targeted reports were released in 2004 which changed the way the Government  viewed the significance of family violence. One report by Vic Health
column2: supported

column1: by DHS
column2: looked at the contribution of family violence to Victoria’s disease burden and the

column1: results were startling. It found that intimate partner violence accounted for nine percent of the
total disease burden for women aged 15-44
column2: contributing more than obesity
column3: illicit drugs and

column1: alcohol. Intimate partner violence had a considerable impact on mental health
outcomes such as anxiety
column2: depression and suicide. The other report
column3: by Access Economics

column1: estimated the total cost of domestic violence to the Australian economy during 2002-2003
was in the region of $8 billion. This included costs to future generations. It was
estimated that there had been more than 400
column2: 000 victims of domestic violence who bore the

column1: greatest share of the costs
column2: however
column3: the expense to state and federal governments was placed

column1: at over $1 billion that year. These reports spoke language Cabinet could understand and in 2005 funding was secured
column2: and thus the second main objective of the Committee was achieved. ";2;4;5;Off;1;3;3;Off;1;1;1;Off;2;5;5;2;2;2;Off;Off;2;2;2;Off;2;2;2;Off;1;3;4;4;1;1;1;1;1;1;1;1;Off;Off;Off;Off;Mostly confident;"

column1: Re (1) At the outset there was no formal goal-setting process. It was all about relationship-building with a view towards eventually doing better for the victims of family violence. However
column2: once the Committee got underway
column3: it became clear that it had two key milestones to achieve:

column1: (a) conceptualizing what an integrated response to family violence would look like in systemic terms. The Feb 2005 Report mentioned earlier delivered this. It proposed an integrated service delivery model (Exhibit D)
and the establishment of a state-wide Family Violence Advisory Committee along with
regional and local Governance Committees to facilitate cooperation and ensure consistency.
(b) achieve a major funding injection in what had always been a chronically underfunded 'sector'. The was achieved in the 2005/6 budget.

Re (2)(3) No clear information about this in the case material. column4: the number of family violence incidents rose because of increased public confidence that reporting now made sense and would elicit a substantive response. It reaching almost 30

column1: recalled that
column2: “we saw new possibilities. We met at the local police station to develop a joint response to transporting unsafe women and children. Most women enter refuge services at night. Typically
column3: they arrive by taxi and there were times when they were followed. Now we had made arrangements for women to be dropped off at 24 hour police stations
column4: dramatically improving their level of safety.”

column1: (3) Cumberland had observed major improvements: “You still hear haunting stories – police taking too long to respond
column2: or high risk women returning home or the problems of indigenous communities where family and community violence intersect. But there is no turning back. The government has significantly invested in reform
column3: the police continue to lead and support services are gradually changing. The courts too have pushed their own boundaries. There are still complaints about uneven responses but

column1: change is happening on the ground.” Gassner also hoped for improved judicial responses including more streamlined process but
that notwithstanding
column2: he reported that police were now taking out significantly more intervention orders. The number of criminal charges laid was also up
column3: jumping by 73 percent in the first year alone. Between 2004 - the introduction of the

column1: Victoria Police Code of Practice - and 2009 there had been a:
• 168% increase in the number of intervention orders applied for by police;
• 153% increase in charges laid; and a
• 22.4% increase in offences arising from breaches of intervention orders.
In addition
column2: Victoria Police had since employed eleven family violence advisors and rolled

column1: out a wide-ranging education program for officers. Gassner noted an attitudinal change shift
from tolerating the Code of Practice to embracing it: “Many members understand it
column2: know

column1: why it is there and are moving into it.” Steendam believed that although there was still a way
for police to go yet

UBC Press.;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;North America;Select;Canada;Select ;Select ;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;On;Off;On;Homelessness;5;1;4;1;1;1;Off;Off;Off;5;3;2;Off;1;1;1;Off;3;4;4;Off;5;3;3;Off;4;1;1;Off;1;1;1;Off;;Off;Off;Off;Off;4;4;4;4;4;4;1;1;1;1;1;1;Off;Off;Off;Highly confident;"In the late 1990s homelessness began to grow at an accelerated pace in Canadian cities
column7: in part due to previous central government spending on affordable housing being withdrawn in the mid-1990s as part of an effort to reduce the Government of Canada’s large deficits. After deficits came under control
column8: the central government returned to the issue of affordable housing and homelessness with their National Homelessness Initiative (NHI)
column9: but at a significantly reduced spending rate
column10: and thus time emphasized a partnership model to address these issues whereby local government and civil society groups and service providers in 60+ cities in Canada would be incentivized
column11: with federal dollars
column12: to come together to form a plan to address homelessness and would jointly decide how to spend those federal dollars supporting homelessness services delivered by non-profit organizations.

column1: The stated objectives were for local stakeholders to form “community advisory boards” (CABs) that would collaborate to develop a locally-specific plan to address homelessness and this group would also make decisions on how to invest the federal government’s dollars towards this effort. The requirement to form a CAB made up of diverse actors from civil society
column2: non-profit and local government was part of an intentional effort to get the broader community to sit down together to discuss
column3: debate and form a consensus around what ought to be the priorities for investments intended to address homelessness. The programs funded had to receive matched funding from other levels of government or organizations working in the field
column4: and thus it was structurally designed to force organizations to work together
column5: partner and collaborate in the provision of services at the local level. This sought to address a key problem of service providers working in isolation of each other and
column6: sometimes
column7: in a competitive position with each other in terms of accessing public dollars to support their programs. Thus
column8: there are two levels of collaboration in this case: collaboration at the level of homelessness policy planning by key stakeholders and local government
column9: and collaboration at the level of service provision.

column1: The ongoing challenge with collaborative governance in this context is that many of the actors involved in the collaboration which prioritizes investments and allocates government funds are the same people who may be vying for those funds. As such
column2: there are procedures in place to avoid directly voting on one’s own programs for funding
column3: but it does not eliminate the perceptions of conflicts of interest. It can be difficult for administrative managers of the collaboration to recruit and retain stakeholders who have no direct interest in the decisions. There is also frustration among some in the collaboration that they do a lot of collaborative work for relatively little money for programs at stake
column4: and that the collaboration ought to pursue larger goals of encouraging the local governments to do more to address homelessness and to try to affect public opinion. The collaboration has thus evolved over the years
column5: in particular shifting to a broader effort to mobilize local governments to do more and generate greater awareness among local citizens to the issues of homelessness (evolution captured in Doberstein 2016 UBC Press book).";2;1;Externally directed by law or authority;1;2;Off;5;4;3;3;2;4;Off;Off;4;Highly confident;"Prior to the creation of the National Homelessness Initiative (NHI) that incentivized the creation of collaborative governance groups at the local level in 60+ cities in Canada in 2000
column6: there was virtually no local policymaking effort around homelessness in Canadian cities. The non-profit service sector was characterized by minimal cooperation
column7: at times competitive relationships
column8: and a lack of trust. Many reported that they often did not know what other organizations did in terms of services or how the collection of funded services across the city fit together as a whole.

column1: The NHI was created by the Government of Canada (GoC) in 2000 with collaboration and partnership in mind as a way to bring together local stakeholders to address the above problems
column2: but also because they needed them to be the drivers of the policy response. A central part of the philosophy of the NHI was to create a national homelessness initiative not based an explicit set of policies determined by the GoC
column3: but rather by allowing local communities to devise locally-specific responses to their unique needs. There are political reasons perhaps unique to Canada that in part drive this: the province of Quebec strongly resists the central government imposing policy directives on it or its cities
column4: so the alternative of top-down policy directives was not  feasible. But there was also a sense that even if the GoC wanted to impose a country-wide homelessness policy directive
column5: they were not equipped with the knowledge or expertise to devise such a policy
column6: and that what may work for Vancouver may not work for Montreal
column7: given the different conditions across the large country. The government was thus dependent on the expertise of local stakeholders to devise a plan and to help make funding decisions.

column1: Local communities would get access to NHI dollars for their city or region if they formed a local collaborative governance entity and developed a plan after consulting with the broader community. With a plan in place
column2: they would then fund homelessness programs delivered by non-profit organizations consistent with the priorities identified in their plans. Thus local governments and stakeholders were incentivized to come together by new funding promised that they would have considerable delegated power in which to decide where that money flowed in the community. They had wide latitude to shape where that money went
column3: with little direction from the GoC. These are the biggest draws among participants in the collaboration when interviewed. Most predicted when asked if that the collaboration would fold/collapse if the funding piece was withdrawn.

column1: Challenges to the collaboration arose when a new Conservative government came to power at the GoC in 2006 which began to add conditions on the funding envelope
column2: in particular a mandate that 65% of the funding must be directed towards “Housing First” programs
column3: which is one (of several) policy approaches in the field of homelessness. Many local collaborations around Canada balked at the new restrictions on their policy planning efforts
column4: as it curtailed the collaborative efforts among the community to prioritize actions unique to their local needs. Yet in this case the GoC is applying a universal standard across all cities in the country
column5: which challenged the local-ness of the collaboration and undermined the authority granted to the collaboration. This caused several collaborations to become very weak and membership to decline as the incentive to participate was dramatically lowered given the constraints on their independence from the govt.";20+;20+;20+;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Yes;Yes;Off;Yes;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;3;4;Off;5;2;2;4;Off;5;2;4;3;3;Off;4;Off;Highly confident;"The NHI by the Government of Canada (GoC) had several grounds rules for the local collaborations. It needed to be comprised of local government and stakeholders (ie. service providers
column6: housing experts
column7: mental health policy professionals
column8: etc.)
column9: they needed to consult with the wider community and devise a local plan to address homelessness to be submitted to the relevant GoC Minister for approval. When determining how to allocate the funds provided to them by the GoC
column10: they had to adhere to typical government standards: publicly post a call for program proposals
column11: adjudicate the submissions in a consistent manner
column12: and submit their recommendations to the GoC Minister. Much of this process would be overseen by a regional GoC staff member who worked with the local collaboration to make sure their activities aligned with GoC rules.

column1: The GoC placed few explicit rules on inclusiveness of the collaboration
column2: but it was generally understood that there needed to be representatives from local non-profit service delivery organizations
column3: as well as local government. Some local collaborations were large
column4: with active membership exceeding 25 representatives (e.g. Vancouver)
column5: and others were relatively small
column6: with about 7-10 (e.g. Toronto). The GoC would submit feedback to the collaboration after receiving their required annual reporting
column7: which includes a list of their membership
column8: if they felt the membership was insufficiently diverse
column9: but there were no universal standards that the local collaborations had to meet in terms of inclusiveness.

column1: Decision-making in these collaborative venues across the country is transparent to the funder
column2: the GoC
column3: which has regional staff representatives present at all major decision moments
column4: and typically even at the routine meetings throughout the year. But these collaborations are not transparent from the perspective of the community or citizens
column5: as in many cases they are unadvertised meetings and decision meetings are closed to protect the information of service organizations who are under discussion. Although technically they are open to the public
column6: there is little active transparency among these local collaborations whereby they promote their meetings
column7: provide agenda items
column8: and publish meeting minutes online. These can all be requested by a citizen through freedom of information protocols
column9: although this may be costly and time-consuming.

column1: Various collaborations that were created in response to the NHI in Canadian cities have undergone considerable evolution in their institutional architecture since their creation in 2000. Some
column2: like the collaboration in Vancouver
column3: have at times oscillated from the collaboration’s board being the principal policy venue doing most of the work
column4: to one in which a smaller set in an executive council meet more frequently and the larger board meets much less frequently (ie. a couple times per year). Others
column5: like in Calgary
column6: have remained very large
column7: but with considerable turnover of representatives over the years. These institutional governance changes reflect the challenge of sustaining collaboration over a long period of time
column8: with burnout
column9: frustration
column10: in-action
column11: or otherwise as reasons for trying out new approaches. Yet the basic structures of governance as informed by the GoC as part of the enabling program have more or less remained constant since 2000. But how that is operationalized at the local level evolves at the margins.

column1: ;Off;Yes;Off;Yes;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;5;4;3;Off;5;5;3;Off;4;4;3;Off;4;Off;2;2;Highly confident;Leadership in the NHI local collaborations was provided at two levels: (i) the GoC as a “metagovernor” of the collaboratives
column2: setting the rules under which they operate in order to access funds
column3: and (ii) the chair position of the collaboratives at the local level.

column1: The GoC leadership was largely structural in form
column2: meaning set forth in governance procedures enforced by the GoC Minister through regional GoC staff. This leadership ensured that local collaborations adhered to the mandate set forth in the NHI program
column3: namely that a group of local government and stakeholders formed the core collaborative body
column4: that they produced a plan to address homelessness informed from community consultation and deliberation
column5: and that the investments made by them using GoC funds were technically eligible (ie. not being directly towards non-homelessness initiatives). The ongoing leadership and oversight was conducted by regional GoC staff
column6: often junior level bureaucrats
column7: under the direction of the Ministry in Ottawa. This leadership form allowed for flexibility at times
column8: given the nature of the program
column9: but also was hampered by the GoC staff being junior and thus were in essence translators and interpreters of GoC procedures to the local level.

column1: The other level of leadership was at the local collaborative level
column2: which was typically a non-profit organization leader selected from among the membership of the collaborative to take the chair or co-chair position. This leadership has few executive responsibilities
column3: and instead was an individual who would preside over the regular meetings of the collaborative and be in more frequent contact with administration staff in order to complete the administrative work required to fulfill the collaborative’s mandate. Chairs or co-chairs would often serve as the public face of the collaboration in media stories and advocacy efforts
column4: as well as travel the country to learn about what other NHI collaboratives were doing with respect to governance
column5: policy and programs.

column1: Leadership at the collaboration level often had few independent tools in order to facilitate more collaboration among the membership beyond the mandate of the NHI program
column2: largely due to them not necessarily being a representative of a major government or societal entity that could incentivize change or collective will formation on policy. Their success would largely hinge on the personal characteristics and abilities to encourage further collaborative work and exchange. These are unpaid positions
column3: and thus without secondment or any other mechanism to reduce their already high workload with their home organization
column4: chair burnout occurred at times
column5: or alternatively chairs would limit their work in the collaboration to the narrow mandates of the NHI funding program.

column1: ;5;5;3;Off;5;4;5;Off;2;2;1;Off;5;5;4;Off;2;2;4;Off;5;1;4;1;3;Off;Off;2;3;1;3;Off;Highly confident;One of the main outputs of the collaboration is to review homelessness program proposals from service providers and collectively make decisions to fund them or not
column2: within the funding envelope provided by the GoC
column3: and consistent with their locally-determined homelessness plan.

column1: The Metro Vancouver homelessness collaboration issued a call for proposals for local homelessness and housing service providers to apply for funding of programmes for up to 2 years. The proposed programmes included providing outreach services
column2: shelter and supports
column3: transitional housing
column4: mental health and addiction treatment
column5: life skills programmes and youth safe houses
column6: among others
column7: across the Vancouver area. To review the proposed programmes and decide which among them to support as the policy response
column8: the twenty-four members of the collaborative formed a special review committee
column9: which would collectively deliberate and decide on the investment priorities. The decision-makers consisted of diverse civil society representatives from homelessness service providers
column10: client group representatives (youth
column11: Aboriginals
column12: women) and community-based philanthropic organizations in four groups (each consisting of five to six members) to share the burden of reviewing the homelessness programme proposals. Each member individually reviewed and scored their group’s share of the proposed programmes and then all met collectively to deliberate which among them should be prioritized and receive investment.

column1: As a researcher
column2: I was able to observe these deliberations as part of the decision-making process
column3: as well as gain access to each decision-maker’s individual scoring sheets for each program proposal in order to analyze them. A major question I sought to examine is: Are collaborative governance deliberations actually transformative (such that actors change their perspectives)? After all participants completed their individual evaluations of the programme proposals assigned to their subgroup
column4: they met collectively to discuss each programme
column5: deliberated over their strengths and weaknesses before selecting those which would receive investment. Deliberations on each proposed programme ranged from 20 minutes to over an hour
column6: followed by several hours of synthesizing and mapping out the service and policy landscape they were creating with their decisions. The deliberations were demonstrably transformative
column7: as evidenced by Figure 2 in the PMR article
column8: which shows how the initial rankings based on the aggregation of individual scores by the participants changed quite substantially after deliberations.

column1: The changing of minds in this context was not fundamentally characterized by compromise
column2: but rather was about learning
column3: persuasion and transformation. Examples identified from participant observation can help demonstrate how arguments were accepted
column4: transformed or ejected from deliberations
column5: and ultimately shifted the collective policy choices. In the deliberations
column6: with some of the most significant shifts in ranking of preferred programmes
column7: participants introduced new data and the perception of the value of the proposed programme changed among other members. New data included knowledge about what was happening on the ground (e.g. a shelter in the area is about to close)
column8: or correcting a misconception about the organization or proposed programme.

column1: This process in terms of deliberations among collaboration members to arrive at funding decisions for homelessness programs remains largely the same over time
column3: which emphasizes community input and control into investment decisions.";5;5;5;Off;4;3;2;Off;4;4;5;Off;1;1;1;5;5;5;Off;Off;1;1;1;Off;1;1;1;Off;5;3;2;1;4;4;5;5;4;1;1;1;Off;Off;Off;Off;Highly confident;"The goals of the local collaborations are formulated at two levels: (i) the GoC core objectives to mobilize a community response to homelessness
column4: and (ii) the particular priorities of a local collaboration informed by consultations and deliberations in the community that form the plan to address homelessness. On the first level
column5: a key principle behind the GoC approach when this program was created in 2000 was to allow the local collaborations wide flexibility in terms of how and where they wished to invest homelessness funds after a community-driven process to shape policy priorities. Yet as mentioned in Question 21
column6: challenges to the collaboration arose when a new Conservative government came to power at the Government of Canada in 2006 which began to add conditions on the funding envelope
column7: in particular a mandate that 65% of the funding must be directed towards “Housing First” programs
column8: which is one (of several) policy approaches in the field of homelessness. Many local collaborations around Canada balked at the new restrictions on their policy planning efforts
column9: as it curtailed the collaborative efforts among the community to prioritize actions unique to their local needs. Yet in this case the Government of Canada is applying a universal standard across all cities in the country
column10: which challenged the local-ness of the collaboration and undermined the authority granted to the collaboration. This caused several collaborations to become very weak and membership to decline as the incentive to participate was dramatically lowered given the constraints on their independence from the government.

column1: On the second level of how goals of the collaborations are formulated and monitored—that is
column2: at the local level—the local collaborative bodies
column3: in advance of preparing or updating their community plans (which occurs every 5-10 years
column4: depending on the particular city in Canada)
column5: typically engage in community forums
column6: working groups
column7: and other forms of engagement with stakeholders and individuals experiencing homelessness in order to help shape policy priorities for the plan. Much of this engagement is targeted to stakeholders
column8: not the general public
column9: however.

column1: Alongside the day-to-day supervision of the local collaborations by the GoC regional staff
column2: as detailed above in Question 37
column3: the chief formal mechanism of accountability is formal reporting to the GoC
column4: the funder. The local collaboration’s membership and community plan
column5: as well as their funding decisions
column6: need to be formally approved by the relevant GoC Minister. In particular
column7: the local collaboration required to produce a Community Plan Assessment (CPA) for the federal government outlining how the funding allocations are consistent with the priorities identified by the community and demonstrating the incremental impact of the program on homelessness in the locality. Various members of local collaborations in the country
column8: and their administrative support staff
column9: complain of the highly detailed and routine reporting required by the GoC for this program
column10: given how little government funds are at stake in the grand scheme of GoC spending.

column1: Citizens are generally not aware of the activity of the local collaborations
column2: as they are generally not publicized and their proceedings not subject to active transparency protocols.  Thus
column3: accountability flows entirely “upward” to the GoC Minister
column4: not “downward” to the community.  ";5;5;5;Off;1;1;1;Off;4;2;2;Off;1;1;1;Off;4;3;3;Off;Off;4;3;3;Off;3;1;1;Off;1;1;1;Off;;Off;Off;Off;Off;5;4;3;3;3;3;1;1;1;1;1;1;Off;Off;Off;Off;5;4;3;1;1;1;5;4;3;Off;Off;Off;5;4;3;3;4;4;1;1;1;1;Off;1;1;Off;Off;;5;4;3;1;1;1;3;4;4;5;4;3;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Highly confident;"The outputs of the collaboration include (i) devising a community-informed and locally-specific plan to address homelessness
column5: (ii) collective deliberations on how to invest GoC dollars in the region
column6: (iii) additional spillover actions beyond the funding piece but emerge from being brought together in a collaborative space (ie. formulating Homelessness Action Week in Metro Vancouver
column7: a community mobilization to raise awareness of homelessness as a problem in the region).

column1: Perhaps the most observable outcomes of the collaboration from my research is when collaboration members come together to deliberate over whether to fund certain homelessness services and programs. I observed these deliberations and compared them to analogous funding decision-making in the absence of collaboration (ie. within a bureaucracy) and found that the process and outcomes are entirely different.  The collaborative environment of decision-making revealed that diverse community stakeholders involved in the collaboration think about homelessness rather differently from each other
column2: which leads to productive and interesting discussions among them when brought together
column3: often revealing misunderstandings or narrow thinking that is corrected as they deliberate.  Contrast this with government bureaucrats
column4: which my PMR article revealed think about the issues and make assessments on proposed homelessness services and programs rather similarly; that is
column5: there is a “collaborative advantage” when diverse local stakeholders come together to prioritize investments and make decisions
column6: which is lost in alternative scenarios when bureaucrats control this process.

column1: Despite witnessing a “collaborative advantage” in decision-making regarding homelessness programs
column2: the effects on the raw numbers of people experiencing homelessness are not detectable. In fact
column3: homelessness continues to rise in virtually all Canadian cities. The local collaborations are not to blame for this
column4: as they control only a fraction of the total funding and policy space as it relates to homelessness—in Canada
column5: provincial governments are the real major players
column6: with control over major funding sources related social assistance
column7: affordable housing
column8: homelessness services
column9: etc. But the fact that the local collaborations are doing good work at mobilizing a more coordinated community response to homelessness
column10: but homelessness continues to grow
column11: can be frustrating for those involved in the collaboration
column12: and can undermine the legitimacy of the collaboration itself among the public.";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

column10: citizens opposed plans by the regional government (province of South-Holland) to designate the Broekpolder area as a location for ‘rural living’
column11: and to build country houses. This plan fermented significant opposition in the local community of Vlaardingen
column12: which resulted in ten thousand signatures against the country houses. The government subsequently decided not to take any action until 2010. Citizens wanted this area to remain undeveloped
column13: to provide leisure
column14: sport
column15: and educational opportunities. They also proposed that they develop and maintain the area directly as a community organization. In response
column16: the council agreed to provide more opportunity for local engagement and self-organization.

column1: From 2007 to 2008
column2: the citizen group took the lead to further elaborate the governance experiment in cooperation with the Mayor and Aldermen. They came up with the idea to develop a covenant to formalize agreements and conditions concerning the extent and form of the citizen initiative. The civil servant
column3: alderman and leading citizens worked closely to jointly develop a policy note that later evolved into a social contract in which the citizens’ initiative (Federation Broekpolder) and its relationships with the municipality (civil service
column4: Mayor and Alderman
column5: and City Council) were elaborated (co-creation).

column1: During 2009-March 2010
column2: the Federation had the task of developing a formal plan - the Integral Area Development and Maintenance Plan - to (re)develop and maintain the area. The Plan was prepared and developed by prioritizing a few projects: The development of a core nature area
column3: archaeological education center
column4: activity forest
column5: and small harbor. In this round
column6: the citizen initiative was discussed a couple of times in the city council. The integral area plan developed was formally approved by the council
column7: which was still obligatory. Moreover
column8: a new regional manager was appointed by the municipality with the task of enhancing its relationship with the Federation.

column1: During (April 2010-2011)
column2: a local government election took place. As a result
column3: a new alderman was appointed to deal with the Broekpolder dossier. He was not in favor of this citizen initiative
column4: and one of first things he did was to re-allocate the budget for the Broekpolder
column5: making it no longer exclusive. He put this previously allocated money into a general budget for green area development
column6: and it became harder for the Federation to get its ideas financed by the municipality. Their projects subsequently came to a halt. The interrelationship between the Federation and the municipality became troublesome (avoidance).

column1: In the next period (2011-2014)
column2: the alderman moved on for political reasons
column3: and again a new alderman was appointed. This alderman has a more positive view of the Federation
column4: revitalizing interaction between the Federation and the municipality. This connection was strengthened further when the civil servant who was active in the first round was reassigned as the municipality’s ‘program manager for participation’ in order to develop a strategic political role for participation and self-organization. The alderman
column5: program manager and regional manager for Broekpolder looked for renewed interaction with the board of the Federation (co-creation). However
column6: budgetary problems remained. The Federation was still looking for broader connections with private and public organizations to get a public-private-society partnership arranged in which different organizations show commitment (financially or in other ways) to the citizen initiative.

column1: ;2;2;Self-initiated by participants;2;4;Off;3;4;3;3;4;4;Off;Off;3;Highly confident;The Broekpolder is an old recreational area of approximately 300 hectares in the northwestern part of the city Vlaardingen. In early 2000
column2: the city and the province of South-Holland had plans to build houses in the area. The Broekpolder was designated as a search location for ‘rural living’ by the regional government.  This caused a large protest in the local community
column3: which resulted in ten thousand signatures against the arrival of country houses in the Broekpolder. The regional government decided not to take any initiatives until 2010 in order to realize rural living.

column1: Meanwhile a few of (politically) active citizens who knew each other quite well of Vlaardingen had gathered
column2: in order to maintain the open and green character of the area. This group of 30 citizens organized at the end of 2002 a number of meetings where citizens were invited to consider the future of the Broekpolder. The civil servant
column3: alderman and leading citizens worked closely to jointly develop a policy note that later evolved into a social contract in which the citizens’ initiative (Federation Broekpolder) and its relationships with the municipality (civil service
column4: Mayor and Alderman
column5: and City Council) were elaborated.

column1: With regard to its representativeness and creating support for ideas and plans
column2: the Federation is focused on creating linkages to municipality (council
column3: administration and civil service) and broad society in Vlaardingen. It has several informal links to key players in the civil service and Mayor and Aldermen. The vision document for the area is developed with the consent of the council and administration. The Federation also realizes to involve the broader public in the development of the vision document and the specific projects it embraces.

column1: There was a high sense of interdependency
column2: as the local government saw the community initiative as an import asset in developing community support and legitimacy for the area development. The local government also had developed policy notes (political agreement) to enhance public participation and self-reliance in the community of municipality of Vlaardingen. For the citizens
column3: they depended on the financial resources from the local government
column4: their expertise on legal and procedural matters. The community were highly educated so they knew quite well what plans to develop that were feasible. Sometimes civil servants and external experts were involved to increase their knowledge and expertise for developing the area.

column1: An important change was when a new Alderman came in that was less supportive to the community initiative and the wider collaboration between municipality and community initiative. Budget cuts came and civil servants were halted in joining the collaboration. Also the politicians became more reluctant in getting involved in the collaboration. After the leave of this Alderman
column2: a new came in
column3: and with this fresh political person the collaboration increased again. There was now more political legitimacy and support for the collaboration. Although
column4: the collaboration was not that intense anymore as in the middle of the process. Representative of the community initiative wanted to become less dependent from the municipality and looked for new partners
column5: like the regional government
column6: private actors (banks
column7: investors
column8: philanthropic institutes
column9: health care organizations
column10: etc.).

column1: ";1-mei;6-okt;nov-15;Off;Yes;Yes;Off;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;4;4;Off;4;3;3;3;Off;2;2;4;4;4;Off;3;Off;Highly confident;" This citizens’ initiative was formalized on October 5
column2: 2006 in the Foundation Federation Broekpolder. The foundation has two goals):

column1: (a) in the broadest sense development and maintaining of the area Broekpolder through sport
column2: recreation
column3: culture
column4: cultural history
column5: nature and education;

column1: (b) take care of the common interests of the users of the Broekpolder on a voluntary basis.

Municipality (the administration) and the Federation jointly developed a policy note that was later on developed into a social contract in which the citizens’ initiative and its relationship with the municipality were elaborated. Special attention was paid to the degree and the extent of citizen participation and initiative of the Federation. With respect to participation possibilities a distinction between area maintenance and regional development of Broekpolder was made. With regard to the maintenance activities
column2: the Federation was allowed to give a qualified advice on the contract extension of the Board which is the basis of the performance of daily maintenance in the Broekpolder. The municipal administration can only differ from these advices when she has strong argument for it. However
column3: the Federation should refrain from a direct interference with the normal daily maintenance.

column1: With regard to the regional development two categories are distinguished: small enhancements and large development projects. With regard to small enhancements
column2: the Federation gives binding advice to the Mayor and Aldermen. With regard to the large development plans and projects
column3: the Federation takes the initiative in generating ideas and subsequently develops in cooperation with the municipality those projects. However there is the precondition that the Federation provides societal support for their ideas and plans: it should make enough effort to bring all the interested parties and stakeholders together that reflects the population of Vlaardingen. The Federation gets a budget for their organization and the maintenance and development of the area. This budget is approved by the council. The Federation is bound by this budget
column4: by the overall structure plan for the region and by legal requirements.

column1: The collaborative forums were quite inclusive for a number of reasons. The leading civil servant made sure that administration and municipal council were involved. The community organization made sure that many and diverse citizens were involved (more than 100 volunteers) and implemented a poll among the all residents of Vlaardingen to show their representative power. During the middle and end of the collaboration period (observed) the municipal council was less involved and reluctant to form a portal (selection of members of the municipal council) as first contact persons from politics to the community organization and the collaboration at large. This hampered the political support and input for the collaboration and the initiative.
Decision-making on the side of the municipality became less transparent in this way. The decision-making within the collaboration was fine
column2: as there were public-community groups in which decisions were made. Also within the community organization a board of governers joined frequently and discussed issues and made decisions which were communicated to the community at large at various moments. Although
column3: from the municipal side this representative decision-making was often criticized
column4: as one argued that a few decided for many without proper procedures in place. The community organization was less strictly organized and knew less procedures. column6: and Alderman. The overall leadership was actually done by the chairperson of the community organization. Her leadership style can be characterized as connective

column8: with different emphasis during different stages of the collaboration process.

column1: At the beginning the style can be characterized as transformative and transactional. She took the lead in developing a vision for the collaboration and community organization (together with the civil servant from the municipality). She focused on group formation and developing ground rules and structures for the collaboration.
Later the style developed towards connective/boundary spanning leadership as she crossed various domains
column2: organizations and sectors to develop a more collaborative imperative. She involved public
column3: private and societal organizations and actors and managed to durably connect them. She didn't succeed in connecting the municipal council though. The transactional focus was apparent in knowing what the rules and procedures  in the municipality were and was able to connect to these
column4: keeping administration and bureaucracy on board
column5: although this took most of the time
column6: as she indicated herself. column1: In the collaboration joint forms of cooperation and coordination was agreed upon (see before). The intended type of outcomes was agreed upon soon in the process. The results in terms of area development (leisure

column4: landscape

Together information was gathered to find out about issues and problems in the area and to get to joined solutions.

column1: The collaboration was strategically as well

column1: During the process the council also requested that the Federation/collaboration implemented a poll among the wider community/residents of Vlaardingen city

column1: An official accountability check by external parties or even internally in the collaboration or the community organization never officially occurred. There were more informal checks and balances

column3: which functioned well as never any issues of integrity and good governance were discussed/issued. column1: In the second stage the content of the area development came to the fore. A vision document was developed by the municipal council to show the boundaries/framework in which the content could be developed by the collaboration.
In the third stage (2009-March 2010)

column4: activity forest

column15: -politik/Kommunalbestyrelsen/S%C3%A5dan-arbejder-Kommunalbestyrelsen/Politisk-arbejdsform;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Select;;Denmark;Select ;Select ;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;On;Youth policy;5;5;5;2;2;2;Off;Off;Off;5;5;5;Off;1;1;1;Off;4;4;4;Off;4;4;4;Off;1;1;1;Off;1;1;1;Off;;Off;Off;Off;Off;3;3;3;5;5;5;2;3;4;2;2;2;Off;Off;Off;Highly confident;"Politicians in Gentofte municipality experienced that they spend too much time in the municipal council and the standing political committees on administrative casework while too little time was spend on developing political solutions to important challenges and threatening wicked policy problems in the local community. Moreover
column16: they found that they did not have the insights they and their administrators needed to develop an informed and high quality policy solutions in a number og policy areas. Therefore
column17: they decided to restructure the political system and introduce a new type of ad hoc committees
column18: which today goes under the name 'The Gentofte Model'. Each committee address a pressing policy problem that the Municipal Council decide need special political attention
column19: and is composed of five politiicans from different parties and 10 relevant and affected citizens. The committees are commissioned to develop a policy proposal through a collaborative governance process
column20: within a given time frame. The timeframe vary according to the task. As such
column21: the primary political motivation for ntroducing the Gentofte Model was to improve the knowledge base of the elected councillors and to strengthen their dialogue with local citizens and stakeholders and involve citizens in policy making (City Council 2015). This objective was to be achieved without increasing the amount of time that the politicians spend in tending their job as councillors. Except for the mayors local councillors are lay people with limited time to spend because they in most cases have a job to tend.

column1: On of the first ad hoc committees was dedicated to developing a new youth policy. The case study reported
column2: builds on data collected over the 10 month long collaborative governance process between five politicians and ten young people resulting leading to the development of a new innovative youth policy. The politicians decided to initiate a collaborative governance process because they felt out of touch with the problems and concerns of young people and wanted to initiate a closer dialogue with them to get the input needed to formulate a qualified policy. They  wanted to get a better understanding of problems that young people struggle with
column3: and to harvest the ideas about how the muniticpality can contribute to alleviating these problems and improve the lives of young people. The aimed-for output was a policy proposal to be debated in the municipal council.

column1: As mandated
column2: the Committee ended up producing a policy proposal within the assigned 10 month timeframe. The work progressed as planned over seven ordinary meetings. The members decided to host a youth camp in order to debate a draft version of the policy with a larger group of young people. The committee also decided to form a number of work groups that w with experts and relevant stakeholders. Each workgroup was assigned to produce certain deliverables in terms of specialized knowledge about a specific topic relevant to the discussions in the Committee. The collaboration process ended with the Municipality Council endorsing the policy without changes.

column1: Over time
column2: as the work in the Committee progressed
column3: ambitions grew among some of the young Committee members. They wanted to initiate concrete activities
column4: and expressed aspirations regarding participating in the dissemination and implementation phase that would start when the policy had been endorsed by the politicians. To meet this request
column5: two of the most eager members were enrolled in disseminating the policy to young people in the local community.    ";1;3;Externally directed by law or authority;2;3;Off;2;3;4;4;3;4;Off;Off;5;Highly confident;"The historical background is that young people and municipal politicians rarely communicate. As such
column6: there was very little prehistory to rely on. The politiicans had very vague ideas about what to expect from the youth and were highly uncertain about how to communicate with them. The chair of the youth committee note that he feared that the politicians would bore the young people to death
column7: or would talk to much and thereby fail to get the youth to talk. Some of the young people explain that they had no prior idea about what a municipality was and what to expect from politician. They were astounded to find that both the public administrators that facilitated the meetings and the participating politicians were nice people who were genuinly interested in what they had to say. The youth were also surpriced that politics was actually very interesting.

column1: The collaboration was initiated by the municipal council who invited 10 carefully selected young people with different backgrounds to become members of the committee. The 10 youth were then invited to a premeeting where the chair of the committee and a young public administrator - a boundary spanner - introduced them to the legal rules and regulations around the work in the committee and the general purpose of the youth committee. At the first ordinary meeting
column2: the 15 participants presented themselves to each other. They each brought an object that mattered to them and told something about who they were. The public administration had prepared a quizz that gave the participants basic information of hard facts related to smoking habits
column3: religious background
column4: education
column5: health
column6: employment etc. among young peopl. Then they formed groups that discussed carefully prepared profiles of young people with different challenges. The meeting concluded with a listing of issues that the members of the committtee wanted to discuss at the comming meetings. The observation of the meeting documented that the collaboration got off to a strong start despite the fact that there was no prehistory of collaboration.

column1: The sense of interdependence was strongest among the politicans
column2: who had a clear sense that they would be unabe to develop a relevant youth policy on their own but the young people had clearly no indication of what they could get out of collaborating with the politicians and the staff at the city hall. They were mostly currious and honoured to have been invited.

column1: As the collaboration progressed the sense of interdependence grew among both parties. The politicans were further reassured that they could not have developed a relevant policy on their own. They found that they received important insights that they did not have before. Moreover
column2: the politiicans realized that some of the youth could play a key role in mobilizing other youth to take part in different municipal projects. The young people on their side experienced that the politicians really listened to them and that their point of view was taken seriously. They also felt that they had a strong influence on the policy output. Their main concern was whether the policy would actually end up being implemented.

column1: The main problem for the collaboration was to keep up the momentum and motivation among all the young people throughout the process. Some of them stopped attending the meetings
column2: and the survey show that they found the meetings long. However
column3: it was not mainly the most vulnerable youth that droped out. The drop outs were equally distributed among youth with different backgrounds.

column1: ";nov-15;nov-15;nov-15;Off;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;4;4;Off;4;3;3;3;Off;3;5;3;5;3;Off;5;Off;Highly confident;"The ground rule of the collaboration was defined in a mission statement formulated by the administration and endorsed by the Municipal Council. The mission statement mandated the ad hoc youth committee to formulate a proposal for a youth policy within 10 months.  The policy was to be formulated in general terms rather than a listing of concrete initiatives to be carried out. Moreover
column2: the statement provided an elaborate set of inclusion critieria in terms of meticulously described profiles of the 10 youth that was to be selected. The criteria aimed to ensure variation in terms of educational background
column3: age
column4: employment
column5: nationality and gender. The concrete young people who fitted these profiles were apponited by the political parties in turn following what is known as the Donish method.  It was agreed among the partied to select youth that were not politically active and associated with a particular party
column6: because the general idea was to get input from ordinary citizens. The politicians were also selected through the Donish method to secure poportionality with seats in the municipal council.

column1: The ground ruled layed out in the mission statement also emphasized that the committee had the autonomy to deside how it would work. The mission statement suggested four meetings and proposed that the committee cound form work groups with external experts and host other events. The youth committee exploited this autonomy to extend the number of meetings to seven. Moreover
column2: it decided to host a 24 hour youth camp in order to secure further inclusion. They also invited different guests to the meetings who would give their perspective on the situation of young people in Gentofte. The guests included different experts and other actors with specific insights. Finally they formed five workgroups along the way that were composed of external experts and public administrators. Each of work groups were asked to prepare a specific input that would inform the discussions in the committee. The chair of the committee and the public adminstrators proposed most of these extra activities to the committee
column3: whcih were then accepted by the rest of the members.

column1: ";Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;5;4;4;Off;5;5;5;Off;4;4;4;Off;4;Off;4;4;Highly confident;"The Municipal Committee had in advance appointed a politican as chair of the Committee. Another politician was appointed co-chair. The chairs planned the meetings in close collaboration with the public administration. A young public administrator was appointed to be in close dialogue with the young members of the Committee between meetings as well as to assist in planning the meetings. The leadership stype was explicitely facilitative and consisted of innovative and creative endeavours to make the young people feel comfortable
column2: and to give them information about the topic without boring them. Moreover
column3: all meetings were varied in form consisting of a combination of group work
column4: small exercises that activated the members
column5: and short inputs from experts. The politicians in the Committee were careful not to speak to much. They were eager to listen and make the young people talk and some of the young people even felt that the politicians were too quiet. As time progressed
column6: however
column7: and the Committee was formulating the policy proposal
column8: the politicians became more active and good discussions took place where everybody were engaged and spoke their mind and did so in a positive climate. The politicians
column9: who came from different parties also managed to keep party disagreements out of the debates
column10: although that might have kept some of the hard issues under the radar
column11: that could have stimulated debate.

column1: The public administrators played a spefic role in the leadership. In the first phase
column2: they mainly prepared and facilitated the meetings. They also stayed in ongoing contact with the young people between meetings in order to ensure that they would attend the meetings and felt wellcome. In the final stages of the collaboration
column3: the public administrators became more focussed on ensuring that the Committee was ready to deliver a policy proposal within the assigned timeframe
column4: and they took on the job of preparing a document that was revised by the Committee members at the two final meetings. In other words
column5: the focus of attention in the leadership gradually changed from process facilitation to product delivery.    ";5;4;4;Off;4;4;4;Off;5;5;5;Off;5;5;5;Off;2;2;3;Off;3;4;3;4;3;Off;Off;2;3;4;3;Off;Highly confident;"The main challenge in the collaboration was that it involved both grown ups and young people. Moreover
column6: for the most part
column7: the collaboration took place at the City Hall in surroundings where the politicians felt at home but were foreign to the young people. In order to overcome this initial bias and barrier and initiate a good dialogue going
column8: the leadership consisting of two politicans and three public administrators
column9: decided to use different artefacts and methods that felt familiar to the young people. Different games were used
column10: and posters
column11: pictures and quizzes were brought into use. Much of the debates took place in small groups. This helped greatly to get the conversation going and the young people took from an early stage active part in the conversation. The politicians highly appreciated the facilitative efforts made by the administrators
column12: but also felt that the process was close to overfacilitated. The politicians were careful not to say too much
column13: which is generally hard for politicians and reduced the benefit they got from the collaboration. When the politicans were visiting the youth camp held halfway into the collaboration process
column14: they held a premeeting among themselves where they discussed what role they whould have in the camp: they decided that they should mainly listen in order not to dominate. The young people appreciated the politicians' willingness to listen but felt that the politicans did not speak their mind
column15: which hampered the dialogue and created some uncertainty. ""We do not know what they think"" one said in an interview.

column1: The communication became more interactive over time
column2: however
column3: as the participants became acquainted with each other and got actively engaged in preparing the policy proposal. The main learning from the process is that it is difficult for politicians to define their role in collaboration with other actors
column4: and particularly with young people
column5: and that tehy tend to avoid the hard political questions
column6: which is taken up  in the political back chambers where only politiicans participate.   ";3;4;5;Off;3;3;3;Off;2;2;2;Off;4;4;5;2;2;2;Off;Off;2;2;2;Off;2;3;3;Off;2;5;5;5;2;2;1;1;1;4;4;4;Off;Off;Off;Off;Highly confident;Throughout the process the leadership and the administration held a keen eye on the formal goals for the collaborative process
column7: and constantly reminded the participants of these goals. Relevant Standing Committees in the Municipal Council had oversight with the process
column8: and received regular updates of the work. We asked the politicians in the Committee if they informed their party groups but few of them did. The latter did create some discontent among politicians who were not members of the Committee
column9: and some of the parties began to organize reporting sessions from the different Committees. Minutes from all meetings were accessible to all politicians at a digital portal. The local media as well as the national radio reported from the youth camp. The final policy proposal was presented at a closed meeting in the Municipal Council. After being endorsed by the Municipal Council
column10: the policy was communicated to the public in the media and two of the youth members were hired to dessiminate the policy to different groups of young people.   ;5;5;5;Off;1;1;1;Off;2;3;3;Off;1;1;1;Off;3;3;3;Off;Off;4;4;4;Off;1;1;1;Off;1;1;1;Off;;Off;Off;Off;Off;3;3;4;5;5;5;1;1;1;1;1;1;Off;Off;Off;Off;2;3;3;4;4;4;4;4;4;Off;Off;Off;5;5;5;5;5;5;5;5;5;1;Off;1;1;Off;Off;;4;4;4;5;5;5;3;4;4;3;4;4;Off;1;1;1;Off;Off;Off;Off;Highly confident;"As commissioned by the Municipal Council
column11: a policy proposal was produced. It was innovative in the sense that it offered a new and nouranced understanding of the policy problem. It did not
column12: however
column13: provide new innovative ideas and guidance regarding how to improve the situation for young people in Gentofte. This can partly be explained by the fact that the Committee was not commissioned to point to concrete initiatives and solutions
column14: and partly because more operational suggestions would probably raise political disagreements.

column1: The generality of the policy proposal and the few concrete opperational suggestions meant that it was uncontroversial for the municipality council to endorse it
column2: but it was equally difficult to ensure that it would get any concrete impact. Thus
column3: it is difficult to determine how much impact it  actually had on the operational level
column4: but there is a general awareness among politicans and public administrators of the need to involve and engage young people actively in decisions that affect their lives. A concrete example of a policy innovation indirectly resulting from the collaboration is the purchase of a specially designed bus that young people can hire and use for street concerts etc.

column1: As an important side effect of the collaboration
column2: noted by both politicans
column3: young people and public administrators
column4: is a stengthening of the mutual understanding and level of trust between the involved parties. The politicians have achieved a much better understanding of what it means to be a young person ion Gentofte
column5: and the youth have a much more positive impression of the municipality and the politiicans
column6: and a better understaning of the importance and difficulties associated with policy making. Of the seven youth that participated in all the meetings and stayed on to the end
column7: most of them state that they would be ready to participate in a similar process if they were invited again.    ";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;
