column2: the IAP was largely centred around a process known as Shared Learning Dialogue (SLD) “which facilitates multi-dimensional information sharing” designed to enable stakeholders from diverse backgrounds and fields of expertise to engage in knowledge transfer (Khan 2018 p.2). ICLEI encouraged Gangtok Municipal Corporation to engage with a broader range of actors than it might normally involve (Archer et al 2017 p.22) so as to garner the knowledge of a wide range of individuals.

column1: Such SLD sessions were therefore facilitated by ICLEI South Asia and the International Institute for Environmental Development (IIED) with key stakeholders in the city including Mayor Shakti Singh Choudhary
column2: and individuals from NGOs
column3: universities
column4: various governmental departments including Public Health Engineering
column5: The Urban Development and Housing Department
column6: Science and Technology and others (ICLEI South Asia n.d). This enabled the IAP to gain insight from a wide range of individuals to identify the main environmental problems facing the city
column7: as well as the most vulnerable groups and ultimately to feed into the city resilience strategy. This consultation took place during each phase of the IAP ensuring that the stakeholder group could provide insight into the main environmental challenges the city faced
column8: vulnerable groups
column9: and means of improving resilience.  Crucially
column10: the SLD process is multi-directional
column11: enabling the stakeholder group to not only feed into the initiative
column12: but to also gain knowledge from the other stakeholders. This two-way transfer allowed the project to maintain public engagement
column13: as well as helping the core climate team tasked with implementation to identify the challenges and opportunities for the city’s initiative. Stakeholders for the group were chosen on four primary considerations:

column1: Public awareness

column3: and buy in has also been essential for the success of the initiative. Both Gangtok Municipal Corporation (GMC) and the Vegetable Market Association have been the key institutions involved in educating the public. In particular
column4: gaining buy-in from vegetable vendors was a challenge in the initial stages that was mostly overcome with the help of the Vegetable Vendors Association in conducting awareness activities and meetings (ICLEI 2018 p.18). Whilst there is still an issue with receiving unsegregated waste from the vegetable vendors (ICLEI 2019 p.18) there has now been broad buy in from the vendors as a result of this collaborative approach between the GMC and Vegetable Market Association (Khan interview 2020).

column1: Regulation and political will as a component that required leadership in Gangtok

The state of Sikkim has been ahead of the curve on state level environmental governance for some time before the introduction of the national level MSW management. Sikkim’s legally enforced shift to organic farming as well as significant moves toward banning single use plastics highlights that an informal movement to improve the environment across the municipality exists within government. Likewise
column2: at the municipal level Mayor Shakti Singh Choudhary highlighted that “The political will in the city is proactive and motivated to implement solutions to common municipal issues. This significantly reduced hurdles to the implementation of the solution as the political buy in influenced social buy-in” (ICLEI 2019 p.17). This is an account that is backed up by a city officer who told us that Mayor Shakti Singh Choudhary himself was the main driving force in pushing the initiative forward (Khan 2020 interview). That being said
column3: despite the informal institution of political will
column4: the formal institution of the 2016 Solid Waste Rules in devolving authority to the municipal level was the main institutional factor enabling this initiative to take place.

b) A bio-composting plant was established at the vegetable market in the Kanchenjunga Shopping Complex. The one-ton Organic Waste Composter (OWC)
column2: installed by Reddonatura India Pvt Ltd and operated and maintained by the Gangtok Municipal Corporation
column3: converts segregated organic waste from the vegetable market into compost
column4: reducing the volume of waste by up to 80-90% (ICLEI 2019 p.11).

column1: c) The installation of the OWC means that organic waste from the market no longer goes to landfill
column2: saving on fuel and emissions
column3: as well as reducing the waste which blocks and pollutes the jhoras. The compost produced is then sold to local farmers
column4: closing the food-waste loop.

column1: The wider population including vegetable vendors were likewise educated on the process of composting and their role in collecting and separating vegetable waste and disposing of it correctly through a campaign of posters within the market itself (Khan 2020 interview) (see below). In addition to this
column2: GMC undertook public outreach programmes encouraging the responsible disposal of waste
column3: as well as the composting of organic waste where possible (Archer et al 2017 p.25).

column1: Given the small scale of the initiative
column2: and the difficulty in contacting GMC officials
column3: likely due to Covid
column4: quantitative data on the effects of the initiative on the local FWEN have been hard to find. The papers covering the initiative
column5: as well as the interviews we conducted
column6: have provided a qualitative picture of improvements to the local environment
column7: in particular the surroundings of the market itself which no longer faces the health and social impacts of vegetable waste being dumped on the street outside the market (Sharma interview 2020). Khan suggested that the composting plant had resulted in a reduction in pollution and blockages in local jhoras
column8: though due to a lack of quantitive data the extent to which this has reduced the issue of landslides is unknown. We know for certain that the initiative has not conclusively solved the issue of landslides due to its small size
column9: as has been confirmed by recent news reports of landslides in the area (e.g. New Indian Express 2020). Likewise
column10: no before and after studies have been conducted to assess the impacts on water quality and thus the exact impact of the plant on water quality in Gangtok is unknown
column11: though with 1 tonne of waste per day being composted (Lama interview 2020) that would ordinarily have gone to the landfill site at Martam it follows that water pollution from the over-supplied Martam landfill site has reduced as a result of the initiative.

column1: Mayor Shakti Singh Choudhary told ICLEI that the initiative has diverted waste from landfill and jhoras reducing energy consumption
column2: emissions and pollution. In addition to this
column3: it reduces the dependency on the city on imported water from the river Rataychu to supply peri-urban agricultural areas which can be supplied by previously polluted and blocked jhoras thereby improving water and energy efficiency (ICLEI 2019 p.12).";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

column4: an epidemic of the Ebola virus spread across Guinea
column5: Liberia
column6: and Sierra Leone. The countries were themselves not able to adequately contain or mitigate the outbreak. Stopping Ebola seemed to require significant outside assistance. In the early and middle periods
column7: most front-line response efforts from outside of these countries were undertaken by non-governmental organizations such as Doctors Without Borders (MSF) (March through August). The World Health Organization (WHO) and the United Nations (UN) more generally recognized in the middle period (July) that Ebola was not being contained and mitigated. The WHO and the three affected national governments created a joint Ebola response plan (on 31 July). The WHO then declared the Ebola epidemic a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (on 8 August 2014). It called on national governments from across the world sought to contribute to response
column8: particularly in the way of health care personnel. Many governments then began to provide funding
column9: health care personnel
column10: and/or other kinds of support. Funding contributions were significantly increased in the weeks following 8 August. On 19 September
column11: the UN sought to further coordinate these responses by creating its ""first-ever UN emergency health mission""
column12: a stand-alone field agency. Health care personnel pledges picked up during September (though most of these were never realized). Actual government-sponsored personnel deployments from abroad also began in September
column13: and increased during subsequent months.

column1: B) The calls for health care workers (HCWs) came from NGOs in the early period. With the recognition of the epidemic as a global health concern in August
column2: the WHO also began to call for more HCWs as the primary goal of international response.

column1: Early period = March-June 2014 -- NGO calls for HCWs
column2: respond in the field. UN agencies (WHO) sends advisors and observers; national governments do not respond.

column1: Middle Period = July-August 2014 -- NGOs call for HCWs
column2: respond in the field. WHO recognizes threat and coordinates with the affected governments. It eventually calls for HCWs and other resources. Funding from national governments and World Bank takes off in mid-August

column1: Late Period = September-December 2014 -- UNMEER created to coordinate responses within and across Guinea
column2: Liberia
column3: and Sierra Leone. 29 national governments pledge HCW support (total on record 6681)
column4: 26 eventually dispatch some HCWs (total on record 2545).

column1: B) While the WHO sent observers and advisors to Guinea
column2: Liberia
column3: and Sierra Leone in response to the Ebola outbreak from March 2014
column4: the mobilization of an international collaborative response kicked off when the WHO and the national governments of the three affected countries launched an Ebola Response Plan on 31 July. This was followed by a formal Public Health Emergency of International Concern by the WHO on 8 August. Finally
column5: the UN created the UNMEER agency to coordinate Ebola responses in the region on 19 September.

column1: C) Explanations for the responses or non-responses to Ebola by governments around the world have not been fully tested. However
column2: interdependency is likely to have figured in the calculations of at least some of the responding governments in the sense that an increasing outbreak of Ebola in West Africa increased the risk of spread through travelers to regions further afield (so public health outside of the affected countries depended on the response within the countries
column3: and in turn
column4: the three affected countries depended on other countries to combat the epidemic). For instance
column5: the United States received a small number of travelers from the region with Ebola symptoms. It also sent medical personnel as well as various other kinds of field response units primarily to Liberia. Responding in the field could arguably reduce to the risk of the Ebola epidemic to US public health. Similarly
column6: many European countries
column7: and the UK and France primarily
column8: responded by dispatching health care personnel to the Ebola affected areas
column9: arguably to reduce the risk of the epidemic spreading further afield. Several African countries also sent teams of health care workers to the area. In turn
column10: the three affected countries depended on these contributions because their own public health systems were unable to stop the spread and treat all affected patients.

column1: D) In the early stage (March-June)
column2: response from outside the affected countries was primarily from NGOs such as Doctors Without Borders. The the middle stage (July-August)
column3: this remained true
column4: but the WHO and the UN more generally began to respond by actively mobilizing the international community. In the late stage (September and onward)
column5: several national governments donated funds and other resources

column1: The bulk of international responses to the epidemic came in the form of funding as well as health care worker deployments. The bulk of funding was contributed during or after the peak of the epidemic in terms of cases. Similarly
column2: most health care workers dispatched from abroad arrived after weekly case counts had begun to decline.

column1: In a report from December 2014
column2: three months after the WHO ramped up an internationally coordinated response
column3: the NGO Doctors Without Borders (MSF) offered a critique of the state of the response to that point: ""Instead of the well-coordinated
column4: comprehensive and expertly-staffed intervention MSF called for ninety days ago
column5: actual efforts have been sluggish and patchy
column6: falling dangerously short of expectations"" (p. 1).

column1: The response process did include innovation. Rather than relying solely on existing WHO and other UN agency resources to manage and coordinate response
column2: the UN established UNMEER as an agency for response (""the first-ever UN emergency health mission""; https://ebolaresponse.un.org/un-mission-ebola-emergency-response-unmeer). However
column3: this step toward an operational field agency was closed down again in July 2015 -- UNMEER was a 'temporary mission'.

column1: It also included coordinated responses to an international health emergency by 26 national governments that included deployments of health care personnel outside of their own borders. For some
column2: this was outside of their normal operational capacities. In addition

column1: Friends of Redington Pass began as an informal voluntary group in November 2009 committed to improving environmental conditions on Redington Pass
column2: a neglected area of the Coronado National Forest east of Tucson
column3: Arizona
column4: USA. Its early membership included local hikers
column5: dirt bikers
column6: horseback riders
column7: hunters
column8: and nearby residents. Initially FRP focused on safety concerns around the recreational target shooting (RTS) areas and the interests of non-motorized recreationists. Towards the end of 2013
column9: FRP expanded expand its mission as well as its Board membership (See next section) to create a broader and more inclusive network of recreation and conservation groups to work alongside the Coronado National Forest and other public agencies. Recreational interests became the central concern along with continuing conservation interests. FRP began pursuing a new role as an umbrella organization for all friends of Redington Pass to serve as a balanced and open forum to discuss our common and diverse interests in the future of Redington Pass. The following vision and mission statement articulates their ambitions and desired outcomes

column1: Vision Statement
Friends of Redington Pass envision protection of the rural backcountry setting of Redington Pass for all recreational and resource users
column2: while providing for public access and management of future diversified recreational growth.

column1: Friends of Redington Pass (FRP) advocates for the responsible stewardship of the Redington Pass area
column2: balanced recreational and resource uses and the preservation of its ecological
column3: scenic
column4: and cultural resources. FRP seeks to bring together representatives from all user groups in furtherance of its objectives and consistent with the 2013 Coronado National Forest Draft Forest Plan Revision.

column1: FRP advocates for:
• Conservation and restoration of sensitive riparian areas along the Tanque Verde Creek
column2: its watershed and wildlife corridors throughout the Pass

column1: • Improved opportunities for dispersed recreational activities on the Pass
column2: assuring clean
column3: natural settings and well-managed motorized and non-motorized uses

column1: • Reductions in unsafe or illegal activities and excessive noise and disturbance throughout Redington Pass.

*Note re next section (a) since I didn’t have room to include it there: There was limited interaction among the participants before FRP started evolving. Several in the core group lived in the nearby neighborhood but were not well acquainted. Some individuals had interactions with users of the Pass when they recreated there. Essentially
column2: there was a void
column3: with the absence of active management by CNF
column4: that needed to be filled
column5: as issues on the Pass became more salient around RTS and OHV use.

column1: ;1;2;Self-initiated by participants;3;3;Off;2;3;3;2;2;4;Off;Off;3;Highly confident;Over the first 3-4 years
column2: FRP reached out to all recreational users in the Pass and learned more about its many highly valued resources and diverse recreation interests as well as the persistent challenges to assuring safe
column3: clean
column4: and enjoyable conditions on the Pass now and in the future.

column1: In the spring of 2010
column2: the Coronado National Forest (CNF) alerted the public to their proposed revision of the Coronado National Forest Working Draft Management Plan (CNF-WDMP)
column3: dated March 2010. This galvanized the interest of several people living near Redington Pass. On March 18th
column4: they convened an open meeting with the CNF District Ranger and representatives of the Arizona Game and Fish Department and the Pima County Sheriff’s office to discuss issues and answer questions about the plan and conditions along the Pass.

column1: Under the umbrella of an informal working group that came to be known as the “Friends of Redington Pass”  or “FRP” they registered their concerns through comments submitted April 30 to the Forest Service that were formally endorsed by the LCE Homeowners Association Board
column2: the Forty Niner’s Homeowners Association
column3: Rinconado Estates Homeowners Association
column4: Tanque Verde Guest Ranch
column5: Cascabel Working Group
column6: Cascabel Hermitage Association
column7: Saguaro Juniper Corporation
column8: Sky Island Alliance
column9: and Environmental and Cultural Conservation Organization. One hundred and ten individual endorsers also signed on to the comments concerning the CNF-WDMP.

column1: A second opportunity arose to provide input to CNF when it issued a draft Environmental Assessment of Proposed Changes to Motorized Travel System. During the summer of 2010
column2: a core group of FRP volunteers went on several field trips with Forest Service personnel to study the road conditions and discuss specific recommendations for road authorizations
column3: improvements and closures. This led to the submission of formal comments on behalf of the Friends of Redington Pass on September 19th.

column2: the group formalized and became a non-profit 501 c (3)
column3: established bylaws and created a board.  During that time
column4: extensive concentrations of lead were found by a board member through sampling on three of the most heavily used sites for recreational target shooting (RTS). Lab results convinced CNF to do their own sampling which resulted in the designation and closure of these sites under RCRA for superfund clean-up. Over $500
column5: 000 was spent by CNF contractors to remove contaminated soils and restore the sites. This led understandably to concerns in the RTS community about the intentions of FRP and its orientation to shooting in the Pass.

column1: FRP learned that in order to address this budding conflict and other recreational and conservation challenges
column2: the Pass needed a strong inclusive network of all user groups to work alongside CNF and other public agencies. FRP participants recognized that they could not achieve their original mission nor a broader more inclusive one unless they also generated a more proactive interest in the Pass and leaned forward to anticipate and advocate for a better future for the Pass. They agreed that they had to work to bring people together for the sake of the Pass and their individual and shared interests.

column1: As a consequence
column3: FRP expanded its vision
column4: mission statement and objectives as well as the composition of its board to pursue a new role as an umbrella organization of all friends of Redington Pass. They began to work together to provide a balanced and open forum to discuss those differences and seek to reach shared goals and strategies together. column1: Board Members Agreement
As a Member of the Board of FRP my duties and responsibilities include:
1. To know the mission
column2: history
column3: policies
column4: and programs of the organization and to be able to describe them accurately.

column1: 2. To work with other board members to carry out the mission of FRP
column2: while constructively representing the interests or concerns of my home organization or constituency

column1: 3. To act as both an informal and
column2: when requested
column3: formal ambassador and spokesperson for FRP.

column1: 4. To attend each FRP meeting with the understanding that during meeting discussions:
a. Civility is expected and negative personal comments are not appropriate;
b. Everyone is to be respectful of one another’s views
column2: even if disagreeing with them;

column1: c. Everyone will try to stay relevant and on task
d. Meeting decisions and announcements will be retained in writing.

5. To support consensus decisions of the board on policies relating to its mission and programs.  Consensus decisions mean that 85% of the board agrees to level 4 or 5 and no one is at level 1 based upon the following 5 point scale:
5= I wholeheartedly agree.
4= I agree
column2: it is okay

column1: 3= I am neutral
2= I disagree
column2: but will go along

column1: 1= I hate this and will work to stop it
Anyone at level 1 should work to present and advocate for a different approach to the issue at hand consistent with the mission of the organization.  If a consensus decision cannot be reached
column2: the board will continue to work on the issue
column3: considering options
column4: including a “minority report”.

column1: 6. To attend as many meetings and other activities of the organization with the understanding that three consecutive unexcused absences from board meetings will be considered resignation from the board.
7. To accept fiduciary responsibility for the organization and oversee its financial health and integrity.
8. To provide oversight to ensure that our programs run effectively.
9. To serve as an ambassador to the community to educate others and promote our work.
10. To participate in fundraising to ensure that our organization has the resources it needs to meet its mission.
11. To act in the best interest of the organization
column2: and to excuse myself from discussions and votes where I have a conflict of interest.

column1: To resign from the board
column2: if I find that I cannot meet the requirements of the board
column3: due to conflict of interest
column4: lack of time
column5: or lack of commitment.

column1: CAMP participants created ground rules for public and working group meetings.
Ground Rules

Work toward full agreement (consensus) on procedural issues

column1: • On final decisions about recommendations to CNF

column4: I would describe my leadership style as collaborative and committed. There was a core group that became formalized into an executive committee of the board that worked together on all policy and strategic directions before presenting them for discussion at the Board meetings. I very much doubt that FRP would have made much progress without committed leadership
column5: nor was it likely they would have done the CAMP. If they had the funds they could have hired an outside process manager/facilitator
column6: but I doubt that would have been feasible.

column1: In fall of 2017
column2: I began to prepare FRP for my departure from the group and spent considerable time working with the board and with the executive committee on leadership transition issues
column3: well knowing how vulnerable these CGRs are to leadership change. This coincided with an organizational transition from a planning group to an operating entity co-managing activities beyond the clean up days
column4: After 1.5 years
column5: they finally had a succession plan and I stepped down (and out). The past year
column6: from my more indirect observations and discussions with the new President and a few board members FRP is holding its own
column7: amending the bylaws
column8: recruiting new members to the board
column9: retaining an outside accountant and attorney (previously an early board member had been an attorney and provide legal services free to the group).

column1: One of the major leadership concerns that has existed throughout FRP’s life
column2: is the CNF leadership and staff capacity which changes frequently and is understaffed and less knowledgeable about the Pass than FRP because of such great turnover. The lag time for CNF response to FRP proposals puts a serious dint in the momentum of the group
column3: particular at this important juncture.

column1: ;5;5;5;Off;5;3;5;Off;5;5;3;Off;5;5;4;Off;5;5;4;Off;4;5;5;5;3;Off;Off;5;4;5;5;Off;Highly confident;Looking at the overarching collaboration dynamics of the FRP group since its inception over the past 10 years. By group
column2: I am referring to the organizing hub of the network which was formalized into a board.

column1: The shared motivation of the group grew over time after initial recruitment and initial successes (CNF reception to FRP comments on the CNF plan
column2: initial closure and clean up of RTS sites). Based on the observations of the group leader
column3: the relational elements of that motivation became more cohesive
column4: including trust
column5: mutual understanding
column6: internal legitimacy and commitment. The CAMP process created a bandwagon effect and as the group diversified and new members came on board
column7: this cohesion was stretched and some interpersonal tensions developed. With leadership change and the coincidental departure of a few other original core members
column8: renewed efforts on the part of the new president are now required to strengthen shared motivation.

column1: The skillfulness of the group as it engaged in defining problems
column2: deliberating and reaching decisions increased over time. With modeling behavior by the president and formalization of ground rules and broad responsibilities these interactions became more efficient and effective.

column1: The capacity of the group for taking actions together increased. More participants volunteered more time and effort and became more knowledgeable about the Pass.  A great example is in the fall of 2017
column2: after the CAMP process
column3: the group agreed there was a need for a second website that featured information about the Pass that would be useful for recreational visitors
column4: distinct from promoting FRP. Each participant was able within 10 days to create excellent content for their interest area.  See http://friendsofredingtonpass.org/about_rp.html   This would not have been possible at the outset of FRP and probably not before the CAMP process. Early on
column5: individual skill sets and resources were acknowledged by the group and then called on and expected to be contributed (distributing flyers
column6: making signs
column7: outreach to media
column8: web development
column9: clean up coordination).  Specialization began to occur. AT its best
column10: there was a good fit between the capacities needed and available through the participants. But this capacity varied as participants withdrew or had to be replaced with others who might not bring the same skill set or resources to the table.

column4: FRP drafted statements of shared values and concerns for Redington Pass that were further refined at a subsequent public meeting. See below:

column1: What People Appreciate about Redington Pass
• Its Rural Backcountry Landscape reveals an open desert mountain pass with scenic panoramas
column2: broad plateaus
column3: and diverse undeveloped landscape features.

column1: • Its Crossroads Location links two watersheds east to west and two mountain ranges north to south
column2: providing habitat for diverse plants and animals and multiple access points and corridors for wildlife movement and human recreation.

column1: • Its Lasting Quality offers visible reminders of the natural and human history of the Southwest still preserved as public lands in an unfragmented landscape.
• Its Open Accessibility makes multiple outdoor recreational opportunities freely available to enjoy by many people in close proximity to Tucson.
• Its Road and Trail Network attracts a highly diverse range of motorized and non-motorized uses as well as access to more distant backcountry destinations.
• Its Rugged Outback Nature creates opportunities for independent recreational adventures shared with others or experienced on one’s own.
• Its Our Pass shared with thousands of people over the decades who hold memories and personal connections to their experiences in Redington Pass.

column1: Executive Summary of CAMP

Friends of Redington Pass convened a Collaborative Area Management Plan (CAMP) process for Redington Pass in 2014. That process brought together a diverse array of people who appreciate the Pass and want to assure it continues to provide multiple beneficial recreational opportunities while maintaining its unique back country environment. A broad range of user groups including hikers and mountain bikers
column2: high clearance highway vehicles and all terrain vehicle riders and motor cyclists
column3: conservationists
column4: horseback riders
column5: hunters and recreational target shooters
column6: the area ranching permittee
column7: and neighborhood associations and adjacent landowners came together to work on four major issue areas that were identified through extensive community scoping: recreational access
column8: recreational target shooting
column9: high use areas
column10: and conflicts among users.

column1: The CAMP recommendations are the result of over a year of study
column2: deliberation
column3: negotiation and consensus building by the CAMP working groups. A synthesis of these recommendations has been organized into five areas:

column1: • Recreational Activities by Location (Western Slope
column2: Central Plateau
column3: Eastern Section);

column1: • Enforcement;
• Services and Facilities;
• Orientation and Education; and
• Monitoring Conditions.

Chief among the recommendations are: the strategy to enhance hiking and mountain biking opportunities along the Western Slope accessible to those with low-clearance vehicles; an adaptive management plan for both designated target shooting areas and dispersed shooting primarily in the Central Plateau of the Pass; maintenance of existing forest service roads and study of some additional connector loops; and improvements for parking
column2: staging areas
column3: signage and other needed services and infrastructure. Where possible
column4: these recommendations come with suggestions for partnering and funding opportunities to assist the Forest Service in carrying out these recommendations.

column8: started to support municipalities

column11: and volunteers to participate in a local network combating functional illiteracy. The goal of this national program is twofold. First
column12: it aims to address the problem of illiteracy in the local community (e.g.
column13: the problem size but also the impact it has on peoples' lives). Secondly
column14: it encourages local stakeholders (e.g.

column1: This case study is situated in City A
column2: a city with over 100.000 inhabitants
column3: governed by a coalition government of multiple parties. The local network observed is one of the 35 networks involved in the national program 'Language for Life'. The main goal of the local organizations involved is to fight functional illiteracy among two different groups: Native Dutch speakers who never gain the literacy skills at school
column4: immigrants who do not command Dutch language skills.

column1: The stated ambitions are:
- to increase the coordination of the collaborative fight against illiteracy
column2: in which the alderman (education
column3: youth and health) of the municipality should take a leading role;

column1: - to improve the guidance and training of illiterate people within the local community.
- to combat illiteracy in the local community.

The period observed covers just a few months (September 2018 - December 2018). The interviews were more of a snapshot of the collaboration at that point in time than a full review of its evolution over time.";3;6;Externally directed by law or authority;2;2;Off;3;3;2;3;4;4;Off;Off;4;Reasonably confident;"Before 2015
column2: there were local initiatives around illiteracy
column3: bringing together some of these parties. The local community college received national funding for literacy classes. After 2015
column4: the local government was given control of these funds
column5: deciding to dedicate 75% of the money to formal courses at the community college and 25% to informal courses by other local partners
column6: such as the library or volunteer organizations.

column1: The local government used the new legal funding power to coordinate and streamline the collaboration. The respondents indicated that they experienced a lack of coordination previously
column2: although they do not rate the coordination very highly at the time of the interviews either.

column1: In this specific case
column2: the following organizations are involved in the fight against illiteracy:

column1: - the local government of City A (both the political and administrative sides of the organization);
- the library
column2: incl. 300 volunteers;

column1: - the social service center
- the regional community college
- the foundation Reading & Writing (in Dutch: Stichting Lezen & Schrijven
column2: L&S);

column1: - the employee insurance authority (in Dutch: Uitvoeringsinstituut Werknemersverzekeringen
column2: UWV).

column1: On the whole
column2: these partners also rely on each to other to identify illiterate people (often by social service providers)
column3: offer formal training (community college)
column4: and informal support (library
column5: volunteers). In practice
column6: financial resources seem to be the main incentive to collaborate

column1: The work of the library
column2: social service center and municipality is closely intertwined due to the local government setting the budgets for the services of these two organizations. The municipality invites tenders for educational programs for both the Dutch native speakers and non-native speakers. One of the most important providers of these programs is the regional community college. The municipality of City A selected the specific community college to organize language courses for illiterate people within its local community and pays for the educational services provided. The role of the employee insurance agency was relatively active
column3: with a particular employee working hard to make her colleagues aware of the role of illiteracy in unemployment.

column1: The representatives of the municipality stated that they did not take the coordinating role in this collaboration
column2: because they felt that other organizations (i.e.
column3: the library
column4: the social service center and the community college) had to have some 'ownership' on this policy domain too. They feared that otherwise the municipality would be the only stakeholder to be held responsible for the combat of illiteracy within the local community. The other stakeholders
column5: however
column6: asked for more coordination and argued that the municipality was the organization designated to do so.

column1: The stakeholders reported that the lack of leadership caused unclarity about the collaborative process and the shared goals and outcomes they were working on. One stakeholder developed a new approach on how to reach out to the target group (i.e.
column2: organizing fun activities and dinners for them)
column3: but most of them did not come up with new ideas on how to solve this societal problem.

column1: There were no changes in the leadership dynamics in the period observed. However
column2: the leadership role was discussed in the focus group and it turned out that stakeholders expected the municipality to take the lead in coordinating the collaborative process.";2;2;2;Off;2;2;2;Off;1;1;1;Off;1;1;1;Off;1;1;2;Off;2;3;2;3;2;Off;Off;1;2;3;2;Off;Mostly confident;"The interviews showed that the various stakeholders that are active in combating illiteracy know about each other. Representatives of the organizations involved meet infrequently
column3: partly due to the lack of an overall steering committee. Some of the stakeholders had experience with such a committee in a neighboring municipality and they were really enthusiastic about this.

column1: Nothing much was said about joint fact finding or knowledge sharing (see also questions 40 and 41). However
column2: what was mentioned are the so-called 'language ambassadors'
column3: which are persons who improved their reading and writing skills and now share their personal experiences with others. These ambassadors are frequently invited by the foundation Reading & Writing and the municipality to talk about their success stories.

column1: No shared outcomes were explicitly formulated. Therefore
column2: it was hard to indicate for the stakeholders whether objectives were achieved. Some of the respondents stated that they would like to formulate some shared goals and outcomes
column3: because they expected that this will help them to convince other potential stakeholders to be involved in the fight against illiteracy as well. Others
column4: however
column5: argued that it is by definition hard to indicate the impact of reducing the number of illiterate people within the local community. In their opinion
column6: it is almost impossible to conduct a pretest and a post-test to measure the outcomes of illiteracy policies.

column1: Three different kind of stakeholders had a monitoring influence on the collaboration: First

column8: and volunteers to participate in a local network to combat functional illiteracy. The goal of this national program was twofold. First

column1: This case study is situated in City B
column2: a city with over 55.000 inhabitants
column3: governed by a coalition government of multiple parties. The local network emerged from existing partners engaged in the fight against illiteracy (library
column4: community college) and new partners (local government
column5: volunteers). The main goal of the local organizations involved is to fight functional illiteracy among two different groups: Native Dutch speakers who never gained the literacy skills at school
column6: and immigrants who do not yet command Dutch language skills. The initiative was bolstered by a regional commitment to fighting illiteracy
column7: to which the local alderman enthusiastically subscribed
column8: endeavoring to boost the local network in his municipality.

column1: On the short-term the stated ambitions are:
- to increase the coordination of the collaborative fight against illiteracy
column2: in which the alderman (education
column3: youth and social work) of the municipality should take a leading role;

column1: - to improve the guidance and training of illiterate people within the local community;
- concretely
column2: about 10% of the inhabitants struggled with illiteracy and the legislative council asked the alderman to reduce this by 1.5% every year. The alderman thought this goal was too specific and ambitious
column3: although he welcomed the degree of commitment from the councillers.

column1: The local government used its new funding powers to coordinate and streamline the collaboration. The respondents indicated that they experienced a lack of coordination before 2015
column2: although they do not rate the coordination very highly at the time of the interviews either
column3: remaining critical of some of the holes and misalignment in their joint approach .

column1: The following organizations were involved in the fight against illiteracy:
- the local government of City B (both the political and administrative sides of the organization);
- the library and its volunteers;
- a local voluntary organization;
- the social service center;
- the regional community college;
- the Reading & Writing Foundation (in Dutch: Stichting Lezen & Schrijven
column2: L&S);

column1: - the employee insurance authority (in Dutch: Uitvoeringsinstituut Werknemersverzekeringen
column2: UWV).

column1: On the whole
column2: these partners also rely on each to other to identify illiterate people (often by social service providers)
column3: offer formal training (community college)
column4: and informal support (library
column5: volunteers). In practice
column6: financial resources seem to be the main incentive to collaborate

column1: The work of the library
column2: social service center and municipality is closely intertwined due to the local government setting the budgets for the services of these two organizations. The municipality invites tenders for educational programs for both the Dutch native speakers and non-native speakers. One of the most important providers of these programs is the regional community college. The municipality of City B selected the specific community college to organize language courses for illiterate people within its local community and pays for the educational services provided. The role of the employee insurance agency is very limited. Its employees are made aware of the possibility to refer illiterate people to the local services on illiteracy. There was no significant incentive found for the agency to do so
column3: although theoretically boosting language skills should enable job seekers to secure employment.

column1: This case study is situated in City C
column2: a city with over 90.000 inhabitants
column3: governed by a coalition government of multiple parties. The main goal of the local organizations involved is to fight functional illiteracy among two different groups: Native Dutch speakers who did not gain sufficient literacy skills at school
column4: and immigrants who do not yet read Dutch. In reaching this goal they aim to develop a project plan for they see the necessity of finding new ways to tackle this societal problem. Currently
column5: they experience a lack of budget
column6: which is seen as one of the major organizational issues the collaboration faces.

column1: (b) The stated ambitions and desired outputs and outcomes.
On the short-term the stated ambitions are:
- to provide appropriate courses for both the native and non-native Dutch speakers;
- to define which stakeholder is (to what extent) responsible for what task in the collective fight against illiteracy.
On the long-term the stated ambitions are:
- to combat illiteracy in the local community;
- to enable people to participate fully in society;
- to reduce poverty in the local community.
There were no further concrete outputs and outcomes mentioned.
(c) Evolution of these challenges
column2: issues and ambitions during the period observed.

The interviews were more of a snapshot of the collaboration at that point in time than a full review of its evolution over time.";3;6;Externally directed by law or authority;2;2;Off;4;Off;2;4;3;3;Off;Off;3;Mostly confident;"(a) The prehistory and past interactions of participants
There were already local initiatives around illiteracy
column2: mainly organized by the local social service center. This public organization was and is funded by the local government. Before 2015
column3: the local community college received national funding for literacy classes. Thereafter
column4: the local government was given control of these funds
column5: and took the lead in bringing together various partners that aim to fight against illiteracy (see c). However
column6: the local social service center and local government played and still play a major role in the fight against illiteracy within the local community.

column1: (b) How the collaboration was initiated
The local government used the new legal funding power to attempt to coordinate and streamline the collaboration. The respondents indicated that they experienced a lack of coordination previously
column2: although they do not rate the coordination highly at the time of the interviews either.

column1: (c) The sense of interdependence between participants and the incentives to collaborate
In this specific case
column2: the following organizations are involved in the fight against illiteracy:

column1: - the local government of City C (both the political and administrative sides of the organization);
- the library and its volunteers;
- a local voluntary organization;
- the social service center;
- the regional community college;
- the foundation Reading & Writing (in Dutch: Stichting Lezen & Schrijven
column2: L&S);

column1: - the employee insurance authority (in Dutch: Uitvoeringsinstituut Werknemersverzekeringen
column2: UWV).

column1: Interdependence
The library
column2: the social service center and the municipality are closely related. This is due to the fact that the local government sets the budgets for the services of these two organizations
column3: which seems to be their main incentive to participate in this collaboration. Besides
column4: the municipality invites tenders for educational programs for both the  Dutch native speakers and non-Dutch speakers. One of the most important providers of these programs is the regional community college. The municipality of City B selected the specific community college to organize language courses for illiterate people within its local community
column5: and thus pays for the educational services provided. Again
column6: financial resources seem to be the main incentive to collaborate.

column1: The foundation Reading & Writing is financed by the Ministry of Education
column2: Culture and Science. However
column3: the main objective of L&S is to provide programs that will help to reduce the number of illiterated people in the Netherlands. This policy goal seems to be its incentive to collaborate with local partners. Finally
column4: the role of the employee insurance authority is very limited. Its employees are made aware of the possibility to refer illiterate people to the local services on illiteracy. There was no significant incentive found for the UWV to do so.

column1: The overall leadership role was in the hands of the representatives of the municipality (i.e.
column2: alderman and policy officers). However
column3: most partners reported there was no clear or strong leadership from the local government. The stakeholders involved were positive about the collaboration

column1: (b) The dynamics and impact of leadership on the collaborative process
The representatives of the municipality played an important leading role in the collaboration. One of their roles was that at least some recurring meetings were held
column2: although not on a regular basis. As a result
column3: various stakeholders frequently met each other. Several respondents indicated that this was one of the strengths of the collaborative process in city C. However
column4: the leadership role of the local government would be weakened when the coordinating civil servant was busy with other dossiers
column5: with no other partners picking up the slack.

column1: (c) Changes in the leadership dynamics in the period observed

There were no changes in the leadership dynamics in the period observed. ";3;3;3;Off;3;3;3;Off;3;3;3;Off;3;3;3;Off;3;3;2;Off;2;3;3;3;3;Off;Off;3;2;3;3;Off;Reasonably confident;"(a) The collaborative process in terms of how the actors interacted with each other

The interviews showed that the various stakeholders that are active in combating illiteracy know each other. Representatives of some of the organizations involved come together frequently in bilateral or sub-group meetings. There was some limited investment in joint fact finding and knowledge sharing. A key role was given to so-called 'language ambassadors'; persons who improved their reading and writing skills and now share their personal experiences with others. These ambassadors are often invited to talk about their success stories.
(b) How they formulated and achieved shared outcomes
The respondents were unclear about how they formulated and achieved shared quick wins (i.e.
column2: short-term outputs). However
column3: they had formulated tangible
column4: strategic outcomes. The desired strategic outcomes were reducing illiteracy - and thereby poverty - within the local community. No insights were given in how to achieve these outcomes.

column1: (c) How the process changed over the period observed

column1: Accountability
The library and the social service center had to provide accounts (i.e.
column2: financial accounting) to the municipality. The municipality
column3: and more specifically the alderman of Youth
column4: Education and Health can be held accountable for policies and spending by the city council. The community college had to prove that it provided the educational programs that the municipality paid for. Thus
column5: the elected official played an important part in rendering account of the collaboration (see also question 51). Furthermore
column6: the programs of the community college needed to fulfill the quality standards of the Dutch Education Inspectorate
column7: which can be categorized as an 'oversight body'
column8: although the illiteracy program would form only a small part of the Inspectorate's remit (see also question 51).

column1: Influence
Different kind of stakeholders had influence on the collaboration. First
column2: the alderman played an important part for this person allocated the financial resources available. Secondly
column3: several policy officers supported the collaborative process on the combat of illiteracy. The main goal of them was to promote collaborative action on solving this problem. Thirdly
column4: the social service center
column5: the library and the voluntary organization involved also influenced the policy. Fourthly
column6: the local project leader of the national Reading & Writing Foundation would monitor the local practices and results in comparison to national indicators and patterns. Finally
column7: there were a few spokespeople of (formerly) illiterate citizens who were frequently asked to comment on the plans.

column1: Stakeholders did provide their own evaluation of the  collaboration in a survey

column1: The societal challenge that the team under study faced was 'disrupting the criminal hemp industry' (Cels et al.
column3: p.2). The team members reformulated this challenge into 'combating illegal grow houses that can cause a fire hazard in residential neighborhoods' (Idem
column4: p.4). In short
column5: the prevention of domestic fires as a result of illegal drug practices thus became the societal challenge.

column1: The various organizations involved (i.e.
column2: national police
column3: public prosecution service
column4: tax authority
column5: municipality of Breda and regional energy provider) were willing to provide support and capacity
column6: as long as their interests were taken into account. The main problem then was that they appeared to have diverging interests. For example
column7: the police and the municipality were planning a large-scale campaign in Breda to fight against organized crime within the local community. The public prosecution service and the tax authority
column8: by contrast
column9: preferred to take on more serious criminals. Finally
column10: the regional energy provider had no interest in fighting organized crime at all; they were in it for safety issues (much less financial issues
column11: as initially expected by others). The major challenge was thus to bridge the differences between the various organizations involved (p.2).

column1: (b) The stated ambitions and desired outputs and outcomes
The team was part of the Organized Crime Field Lab 2015-2016 (in short
column2: OCFL 2015-2016). This experiential learning environment is a joint project of the Dutch Public Prosecution Service
column3: the Dutch National Police and the universities of Tilburg/Harvard/Oxford. Teams participating in the OCFL 2015-2016 were challenged to develop and design creative and innovative solutions for various forms of organized crime with subversive effects. The stated ambition of the team under study was: 'combating illegal grow houses that can cause a fire hazard in residential neighborhoods' (Idem

column1: (b) How the collaboration was initiated
Direct supervisors of the participants
column2: together with members of a dedicated task force 'Organized crime'
column3: had crafted a problem description for the collaboration as part of the OCFL 2015-2016. They decided which professionals were part of the collaboration. They selected a police man
column4: a public prosecutor
column5: a tax officer
column6: a policy officer of the Municipality of Breda and a manager of the regional energy provider. Their proposal focused on drug crimes in the two southern provinces of the Netherlands (i.e.
column7: Noord-Brabant and Limburg). Therefore
column8: all participants selected were working for an organization located in either Noord-Brabant or Limburg (Idem

column1: (c) The sense of interdependence between participants and the incentives to collaborate
The participants had no sense of interdependence at the beginning of their collaborative project. Each of them had his* own ideas on how to approach the problem. For example
column2: the police man and the policy officer of the Municipality of Breda aimed for a large-scale operation at the local level. However
column3: for the public prosecutor and the tax officer
column4: this local focus was irrelevant for they were responsible for the fight against organized crime
column5: notably committed by serious criminals
column6: at a regional level. Furthermore
column7: the manager of the regional energy provider was not interested in crime fighting at all. In short
column8: the participants had different ideas and interests. They tackled this by reframing the societal challenge (see also 13a). This increased both the sense of interdependence with regard to the reframed problem and the incentives to collaborate.

column1: (d) Any significant changes over time in the period observed
The most remarkable change was the growing trust among the various participants and their ability to find mutually acceptable solutions to the societal challenge they aimed to tackle (see also 13a).

column1: The following three lessons for follow-up operations can be seen as the outcomes of the first experiment:
1. Smaller scale: too much households were involved in the experiment;
2. Lower costs: the material costs of the operation were relatively high;
3. Clearer frame: local press and others did not always fully grasp the frame (i.e.
column2: promoting fire safety vs. fighting against organized crime) (Idem

column4: but they felt that too little was achieved. After two years
column5: they discontinued the 'road show'
column6: and thereby also with their collaborative project (Idem

column8: and members kept in touch
column9: but the collaboration as such ceased to exist.

column2: Melbourne;Hayley Henderson;Ausralian National University;hayley.henderson@anu.edu.au;December;2005;Ongoing;Ongoing;December;December;2005;2016;Yes;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;;http://cura.our.dmu.ac.uk/files/2017/08/Governing-in-and-against-austerity.pdfhttps://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/07352166.2018.1516509 ;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Australasia;Select;Select ;Select ;Select ;Off;Off;Off;On;Off;On;Off;Off;On;Off;Off;;5;5;5;1;1;1;Off;Off;Off;3;3;3;Off;2;2;2;Off;2;2;2;Off;3;2;2;Off;1;1;1;Off;1;1;1;Off;;Off;Off;Off;Off;3;2;2;3;2;2;4;4;4;1;1;1;Off;Off;Off;Highly confident;"a) The process of revitalisation in Central Dandenong was instigated by the (regional) Victorian Government in response to urban decay (i.e. flagging retail
column3: vacant buildings
column4: public realm deterioration
column5: stressed services
column6: stagnating population numbers) and rising social challenges
column7: especially growing unemployment and poverty. The centre’s disuse and decline occurred due to a contracting local manufacturing sector
column8: poor past planning decisions (i.e. shopping mall in the same centre) and the rapid suburbanisation of neighbouring municipalities.

column1: b) The Victorian Government embarked on the “Revitalising Central Dandenong” (2005-2025) (RCD hereafter) project in an attempt to restore the “standing” Central Dandenong once had as the capital of Melbourne’s south east through “job-creating economic activity
column2: ” delivering 4
column3: 000 new homes and bringing new residents to the centre
column4: and improving local infrastructure and amenities over twenty years. Revitalisation was planned to recognise the multicultural character of the neighbourhood. In terms of the governance ambitions
column5: RCD was designed to support collaboration between local and regional actors across public
column6: civil society and private sectors.

column1: c) The desired social and economic outcomes of RCD are largely on track to be fulfilled. In 2016 there were more jobs (aprox. 2000) and more residents (aprox. 1000) in the centre
column2: commercial and residential developments increased (over AUS$300
column4: 000 in investment between 2006 and 2011)
column5: and local infrastructure has been upgraded or built (e.g. public library
column6: produce market
column7: theatre
column8: central square
column9: bridge
column10: green space). Deakin University opened a local centre
column11: while Chisholm Institute (a Technical and Further Education college - TAFE) continued to deliver courses for local job insertion. New public spaces that recognise cultural diversity were created (i.e. Harmony Square
column12: Afgan Bazaar and Little India Cultural Precincts) and new community activities have been organised. While there are measurable improvements in public realm infrastructure and the percentage of people engaged in work or study was higher in 2016 than in 2006
column13: the area still faces challenges
column14: including a lack of affordable housing
column15: the rising cost of commercial rents
column16: dwindling services for refugees and asylum seekers
column17: ongoing high (relative) crime rates as well as one of the lowest employment participation rates of Melbourne.

column1: Revitalisation has to date occurred through the active participation of a broad range of actors that has changed over time. The early phase (2006-2010) was led by the Victorian Government’s development agency in partnership with the City of Greater Dandenong. The middle period (2011-2015) was marked by the near total retreat of the development agency
column2: the growing leadership of the local government and the activation of local networks. The role of local cultural and retail associations as well as the creation of the private sector lobby group the Committee for Dandenong stand out in this period. The latter period of the project (2016-present
column3: though only 2016 was part of this study) represents the continuation of the middle period
column4: with early signs of renewed involvement by the Victorian Government in revitalisation efforts. Collaboration modes have evolved accordingly throughout
column5: with increasing local actor involvement. Overall
column6: while temporary institutional structures have functioned to provide basic support for operational matters
column7: collaboration has occurred primarily in an informal and ad hoc way between different actors.";4;4;Externally directed by law or authority;2;2;Off;4;4;2;4;5;4;Off;Off;4;Highly confident;"a) Prior to the introduction of RCD
column8: the Dandenong Development Board (Board) was established (2003) to address the growing issue of urban decline identified since the mid-1990s. The board was made up of nine people including local representatives (Mayor
column9: CEO)
column10: state representatives (from the Departments of Infrastructure
column11: Industry/Innovation) and two persons with business interests in Dandenong. The Board
column12: just like the ensuing RCD project
column13: was subject to the direction and control of the Minister of the Department of Environment
column14: Land
column15: Water and Planning (DELWP). Local actors involved in the revitalisation process interacted in other ways prior to the introduction of RCD
column16: for example on local committees and boards (e.g. involved with the hospital or TAFE)
column17: in organising community events or on a sporadic basis for individual project and policies.

column1: b) When RCD was announced in 2005
column2: the state’s development agency was given a mandate to undertake the project with two partners:

column1: 1. Victorian Government departments (DELWP; Premier and Cabinet; and Economic Development
column2: Jobs
column3: Transport and Resources); and

column1: 2. The City of Greater Dandenong (local government).
During the early period of RCD (2006-2010)
column2: cross-government coordination occurred formally through the Project Control Group (PCG).

column1: Following the early period of mandated collaboration between key actors (post-2010)
column2: revitalisation has been led more by the local government and has occurred through single projects initiated by the City. Some of these local projects were introduced as a result of funding opportunities offered by the State Government (e.g. rail upgrades
column3: Little India designation) or Federal Government (i.e. through the 2011 economic stimulus package). New forms of collaboration at the local level
column4: for example between private businesses with the creation of the Committee for Dandenong
column5: between traders at the Dandenong Market or in designating and delivering new programs for interfaith learning by religious leaders also emerged during this period. These new platforms or networks for collaboration were stimulated by the initial investment made in revitalisation (2006-2010) and receive some form of support by local government
column6: from access to information or services to community grants and ongoing funding.

column1: c) The sense of interdependence between actors relates to the recognition that each relies on others for revitalisation to occur and that revitalisation is in the best interest of all. Regional and local governments rely closely on each other for funding as well as for operational purposes
column2: for example for the local library. Civil society relies on government funding to provide services
column3: such as English language classes
column4: and vice versa. Private businesses rely on governments to fund infrastructure projects that support their operation. The incentives to collaborate relate to the level of interest of each participant in the revitalisation process and occur primarily in an unstructured and informal way
column5: though formal structures may temporarily exist to address particular issues.

column1: d) Collaborative structures set up to support vertical and horizontal collaboration between government agencies were functional during the early part of the project
column2: however they did not lead to any significant changes over time in terms of cross-government collaboration. The most significant lasting changes in terms of collaboration have occurred in the latter stages of revitalisation with stronger local networks and partnerships. ";6-okt;nov-15;nov-15;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;1;2;Off;2;2;3;3;Off;3;2;3;2;3;Off;2;Off;Mostly confident;"a) Throughout the period observed (2006-2016)
column3: collaboration has occurred in a highly fluid and informal way that relies more on the strength of interpersonal relationships than systemised processes. Interviewees discussed the importance of the close working relationships between leaders
column4: in particular that many were embedded in the community long-term and that these individuals’ soft skills engendered flexible and responsive collaboration. At times
column5: committees and boards have been established to support actor interaction.

column1: In particular
column2: the first period of RCD was managed through the PCG. The Victorian Auditor-General found however that it did not operate with “codified procedures
column3: responsibilities and accountabilities for individual agencies” (2011

column5: p.13). In later phases

column8: from the election of members managed by the Australian Electoral Commission to the organisation of regular meetings and clear channels of communication with the Market Board. Another collaboration is the Interfaith Network of the City of Greater Dandenong which brings together leaders from over twenty faith communities monthly to share experiences. Their principles of involvement include co-participation in the Network’s activities
column9: for example informing government on relevant policy issues (disability

column11: participating in the tours of places of worship (e.g. for school children
column12: the police)

column1: b) & c) Collaboration has largely been informal throughout and complemented by two distinct phases of organised approaches. The mandated interjurisdictional coordination with community consultation that occurred in the initial phase (2006-2010) focused on the general theme of revitalisation. While functional for issue monitoring and some aspects of project administration
column2: there were tensions between departments on some issues
column3: such as transport decisions
column4: and difficulties in managing the vertical integration of local and regional governments due to strong imbalances
column5: (e.g. City was required to cede planning powers to the state and was not privy to all financial information). In this regard
column6: some of the core project decision-making were not widely transparent. The Auditor-General’s review of RCD (2011) claimed formal cross-government coordination was “inconsistent” (p.ix) and the reliance on informal approaches did not “promote accountability for actions” (p.9) and “lacked transparency” (p.12). During the later phases of the project
column7: collaboration has continued to be based on strong interpersonal relationships and occurs in an organised way for numerous single issue policy initiatives or individual projects. Our research suggests many of these are lasting
column8: inclusive and transparent within each specific
column9: often single-issue forum.

column1: d) Temporary structures were established to deal with key operational issues during the early phase of RCD
column2: though these were largely eliminated in 2010 and therefore did not leave lasting changes to internal institutional architecture. The greatest change has been activating and strengthening local networks since 2010
column3: including increasing sophistication in the way governments engage with these organised business and community groups.";Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Yes;Yes;Yes;Off;Off;Off;Off;Off;Yes;Off;4;4;4;Off;5;5;5;Off;5;5;5;Off;2;Off;3;3;Highly confident;"a) & b) The form and style of leadership was critical in shaping the style of collaboration. As one interviewee described
column4: it was driven through “a leader-set culture
column5: not bits of paper.” Collaboration was essentially leader-oriented and based on the strength of personal relationships between key actors both in the beginning (2005-2010) with the Victorian Government’s development agency leading the process and later in the project life with the local government taking on the leadership role (2011-onwards). The impact of this style of leadership and collaboration was effective for swift project initiation and definition as well as for focused project delivery purposes. While functional
column6: drawbacks were identified in terms of wider inclusion of diverse perspectives
column7: for example in identifying problems (e.g. car-parking and traffic issues were an unresolved concern for many local businesses in 2016 and 2017
column8: some suggesting low-level interaction with the retail sector as an issue in the project) or for creative problem-resolution. It also created scope for missed opportunities because of the absence of a range of actors. For example
column9: this was true in the RCD project in terms of seed-funding initiatives in the education sector as well as health as these areas of government were not involved as key actors in the project. When leadership was discussed by interview respondents it was often as the antidote to the absence of larger and formal collaborative forums.

column1: c) The most significant change to the leadership dynamics in the process of revitalisation occurred as a result of a change of administration in 2010. The new Victorian Government repurposed the government’s development agency and the project team went from 25 to one person in 2011. This change was disruptive
column2: though not terminal for the project given that most of the investment and major decisions about the direction of revitalisation had been made. It led to a swift and unplanned transfer of leadership from the state’s development agency to the local government. It also prompted local business leaders to become more organised. This is best represented through the creation of the Committee for Dandenong
column3: run by a board of seven local business leaders who developed Strategic Agenda (2015) for the region that sets out priorities for local development. The Committee uses this to articulate joint priorities for local businesses and advocate for continued public investment in revitalisation. As the revitalisation process matured
column4: many existing interactions between local government and community and retail groups have also become more sophisticated through formal collaborative structures. One example of this is the creation of the Dandenong Market Pty Ltd in 2012 with an independent board and committee of traders that manage the City’s market to deliver a financial return for government as well as deliver social responsibilities
column5: including to nurture new businesses and host community and cultural festivals. Prior to this the market was run by a real estate agency without participation in the Market’s planning by local community or traders. Another example of growing community leadership supported by local government is the Interfaith Network mentioned above. The growing leadership role of organised non-government groups also reflects a trend towards greater outsourcing of community services by government. column6: b) & c). The collaborative process behind revitalisation in Central Dandenong can be broken into three main phases. An early phase mandated by the Parliament of Victoria to support the initiation of RCD (2005-2010)
column7: a middle phase (2011-2015) defined by a significant change in custodianship of revitalisation s from the state to local government as well as the invigoration of local stakeholder networks and a third phase in which some local networks show signs of consolidating their roles (2016-present
column8: though the research observation ended in 2016). These periods coincide with changes in the Victorian Government’s administration and relatively strong changes to policy focus each time.

column1: The first phase of collaboration was defined largely by the leadership role of the Victorian Government in initiating RCD. The formal structure for collaboration was the PCB which met monthly to identify project priorities and issues
column2: oversee community engagement as well as to track progress and meet reporting requirements. However
column3: the PCB was found to be “weak” in ensuring “cross-government coordination” by the Victorian Auditor General (2011
column4: p.8-9) due to unclear responsibilities
column5: accountabilities and processes. It was the interaction between key actors that occurred largely outside of this forum in an informal and sporadic way that served as the real operational backbone for revitalisation
column6: including how shared outcomes were formulated and achieved. The following respondent exemplifies this sentiment

column9: have influence and how to get the decisions made…the fact that we had very capable individuals at the coalface meant that you could overcome a number of the hurdles that you invariably face in these projects…Of course in a perfect scenario

column11: great people will win every time
column12: because they'll find a way.” Despite the highly functional nature of this approach there were downfalls in this phase of the project in terms of procedural delays
column13: risks identified by government in financial management and missed opportunities for collaboration
column14: especially in the areas of health and education.

column1: By 2011 the state’s development agency provided only minor oversight of the RCD program while the local government assumed leadership responsibilities for revitalisation. Collaboration processes initiated by the City occur for specific policy issues or projects
column2: for example the new library or the Afghan Bazaar Cultural Precinct. Each initiative is different
column3: though goals tend to be co-developed between local government and stakeholder groups (e.g. cultural groups
column4: retailers). Any policy changes or public works are undertaken by government (or outsourced to contractors)

column6: non-government or co-delivered depending on the case (increasingly less by government as the shift from government-as-provider to government-as-purchaser matures). The second phase can also be defined by intensified collaboration between community leaders and between local business leaders (see Interfaith Network and Committee for Dandenong examples above). The Auditor-General’s review in 2011 stated that the PCB had “not become the robust decision-making forum intended” and reported little evidence that the group effectively governed or monitored RCD (p.10). In the absence of codified procedures to formulate or monitor goals for collaboration

column1: b) During the first phase of RCD
column2: collaboration was seen as necessary for revitalisation and was measured as functional though not well-organised for this goal. Cross-government coordination during the first phase was assessed as inadequate in reviews by oversight bodies. The response provided by the development agency was that weak formal governance arrangements “should not be confused or overshadow the progress that has occurred in Central Dandenong due to the efforts of all parties involved” (correspondence VicUrban
column3: 2011). While several attempts were made to change and strengthen formal governance structures
column4: informal ad hoc approaches prevailed. Given the informal nature of collaboration it was not held accountable to outside parties such as citizens
column5: elected officials or oversight bodies. Interviewees in our research suggested that it was the “relational aspect” of the part of the project expressed through “goodwill and unofficial conversations” as well as the “soft skills of individuals” gave the revitalisation process “traction and effectiveness”. Later in the process of revitalisation the mechanisms of holding to account the different collaborations vary. Where the City convenes an initiative they tend to unfold in a consultative way with opportunities to provide feedback
column6: though the decision-making powers remain with government and some influence by elected officials managed by public servants. Where collaboration occurs between members of the community or businesses
column7: goals are formulated among members
column8: performance is measured internally by members and changes are made to their processes and goals by members without external accounting
column9: with the exception of reporting back to government when funding is granted.

column1: c) The change in collaboration went from highly informal and oriented towards delivery of the Victorian Government’s RCD to focused on locally-led individual projects with continued emphasis on interpersonal relationships in the coordination of different aspects of revitalisation. We observed consolidation in specific collaborative approaches and increasing sophistication in inter-organisational/group interactions in the later phases of revitalisation.

column2: it supported the refinement of project details to match shared desired outcomes and delivery capacities. Second

column7: for example the refinement of public space projects (e.g. pop-up park
