column1: The main societal challenge is to stop internationally operating gangs that traffic
column2: smuggle and exploit children (Cels et al.
column4: p.99). These gangs recruit children from poor families in South-East Europe and incorporate them into their ‘families’. The rules of these families are:

column1: 1. The outside world is hostile;
2. There is nothing to expect from the police or social service organizations;
3. Stealing is a good thing to do; and
4. You can only trust your family (Idem
The gangs forced innocent children to beg and steal at central spots in various European cities
column2: for example at train stations and market squares (Idem
column3: p.100). This case is located in Amsterdam and Barcelona
column4: but the collaborative partners acknowledged that the problem is much bigger. The partners knew that the gangs were also operating in Brussels
column5: Rotterdam and Vienna. The flexibility of the gangs made it challenging for the collaborative partners to get a grip on the situation (Idem

column1: In contrast to the gangs
column2: the public-sector organizations (i.e.
column3: local and national police and public prosecution service) that were involved in this project were less flexible. The various partners experienced that it was difficult to get support (i.e.
column4: extra capacity) from their supervisors for this project
column5: which was seen as the main organizational issue (Idem

column1: (b) The stated ambitions and desired outputs and outcomes
The collaborative partners stated three ambitions:
1. Reframing the problem: the main problem is not the stealing and begging children
column2: but the internationally operating gangs that force them to do so. In other words
column3: the crime fighters should not focus on mobile banditry
column4: but on human trafficking and smuggling and the related criminal exploitation of children (Idem

column1: 2. Gaining insights into the nature and scope of the problem: the collaborative partners had no idea about the modus operandi of the gangs and therefore aimed to get insights into the nature and size of the problem (i.e.
column2: how many gangs and children are involved in these practices; and
column3: how do they operate) (Idem

column1: 3. Developing a problem-oriented approach: the collaborative partners worked together in an unconventional manner (i.e.
column2: collaboration between various public-sector organizations) and therefore had to develop a new
column3: problem-oriented approach to tackle the societal problem they faced (Idem

column1: (b) How the collaboration was initiated

The national public prosecutor on human trafficking and people smuggling announced his idea to start a collective fight against gangs that traffic and smuggle children and force them to do criminal acts. This announcement was made at a meeting of the Expertise Center on Human Trafficking and Smuggling in January 2015. Directly afterwards
column2: a policeman (local police
column3: focus: region Amsterdam) and a chief of the police (national police
column4: focus: division alien identification and human trafficking) joint the project. A few months later

column6: focus: division human trafficking and smuggling) also became part of the team (Idem
column7: p.101). Thus
column8: in total four public professionals and their respective organizations were involved in the collaboration.

column2: De Jong & Cels 2016) concerns collaboration in the fight against human trafficking in the Netherlands in fact comprises three consecutive cases (i.e.
column3: Sneep case
column4: Irina.com case
column5: and Philippine sailors case) in which three Dutch public prosecutors figure prominently.

column1: (a) societal challenges and organizational issues
- The lack of public and political awareness of human trafficking as an urgent yet persistent societal problem
column2: also or perhaps especially so in the Netherlands;

column1: - The limited cooperation within government and between public-sector and private-sector organizations in the fight against this problem;
- The dominant focus on repressive action and enforcement of criminal law as solutions to the problem;
- The difficulty to measure real successes in the fight against human trafficking
column2: beyond arrests
column3: court cases
column4: sentences etc.;

column1: - The lack of appropriate skills among public prosecutors to innovate in the fight against human trafficking.
(b) stated ambitions and desired outputs and outcomes
- Changing public perception about human trafficking in order to garner political support;
- Realizing collaboration among public-sector organizations and engaging private-sector organizations to collectively fight against human trafficking;
- Balancing the effort to prosecute perpetrators with efforts to protect victims and prevent human trafficking
column2: especially under resource constraints;

column1: - Measuring successes in novel ways;
- Equipping the new generation of public prosecutors with the skills to operate innovatively in an increasingly complex law enforcement environment.
(c) evolution of challenges
column2: issues and ambitions during the period observed

column1: Challenges
column2: issues and ambitions evolved over time
column3: throughout the three cases. At the start of the period discussed in the case study
column4: the focus was primarily on creating awareness for human trafficking as an urgent
column5: yet persistent societal problem and increasing public and political support for the fight against this problem. Thereafter
column6: the public prosecutors focused on bringing together the public and private partners that could help them to investigate and prosecute perpetrators of human trafficking
column7: and
column8: beyond that
column9: to jointly develop an approach that was more preventative. This also raised issues around measuring effects (Waardenburg et al. 2018) and
column10: more broadly
column11: with regard to public problem solving and the collaborative process (Waardenburg et al.
column12: forthcoming).

column1: ;4;4;Self-initiated by participants;3;3;Off;3;3;3;3;4;4;Off;Off;4;Mostly confident;(a) the prehistory and past interactions of participants
The three public prosecutors had been working with each other before as part of their regular jobs. Other potential participants were invited to join the collective crime fight
column2: among others during a meeting in which one of them
column3: a chief public prosecutor
column4: presented shocking photos and stories about human trafficking in the Netherlands to high-level representatives of various Dutch law enforcement authorities (Groenleer & De Jong
column6: p.4). Relevant private-sector partners (i.e.
column7: hotels
column8: landlords
column9: physicians
column10: abortion clinics) were approached per case.

column1: (b) how the collaboration was initiated
After the publication of a U.S. Department of State’s (2005) Trafficking in Persons Report
column2: which showed that the Netherlands could do much more in fighting human trafficking
column3: especially for its 25
column4: 000 commercial sex workers
column5: of whom an estimated 50 to 80 percent were trafficking victims
column6: the protagonists posed the question: why had their efforts to tackle this problem been so inadequate (Groenleer & De Jong
column8: p.3)? This set in motion the three consecutive cases described in the case study.

column1: (c) the sense of interdependence between participants and the incentives to collaborate
Right from the start
column2: the initiators found that a host of public and private parties
column3: either consciously or unconsciously
column4: facilitate human trafficking (Ibid
column5: p.3). They therefore aimed at developing a novel
column6: integrated approach in which there would be close cooperation with both public-sector and private-sector parties (Ibid
column7: p.4). A key incentive for these parties to collaborate was the media attention that was generated to put the human trafficking problem on the public and political agenda (Ibid
column8: p.4). This was an effective incentive
column9: as none of the public and private parties wanted to be seen as an enabler of human trafficking.

column1: (d) any significant changes over time in the period observed
The interaction between the three public prosecutors did not significantly change over time
column2: apart from changes in their own positions (one of them became the chief of the Public Prosecution Service). At all periods observed the Dutch Public Prosecution Service took the lead in the collaboration with other parties. The prosecutors invited other public-sector and private-sector parties to join the team if they thought that it was necessary to do so. As a result
column3: the composition of the collaboration varied per case.

column1: The following ground rules can be derived from the three follow-up cases:
- Potential public and private partners need to be relevant

column1: - All partners that are involved in the operational action need to support the action that the collaboration is going to undertake (and otherwise the action plan needs to be rediscussed
column2: see Irina.com case) (Groenleer & De Jong

column1: - All partners that are involved in the operational action share knowledge and expertise with each other (Idem

- Media attention is attracted to gain public and political support for the actions;

Little information is given about the inclusiveness of the collaborative forum(s). It seems that the public and private partners relevant to the problem definition were included in the operations that are discussed in the case study. However
column2: for the second case (i.e.
column3: Irina.com)
column4: it turned out that some important private partners (i.e.
column5: international hotel groups) were not included at the outset
column6: but agreed on a partnership later on (Idem

column1: (c) The transparency of decision making within the collaborative forum(s)
Few insights are provided into the transparency of the decision making within the collaborative forum(s). However
column2: in the second case (i.e.
column3: Irina.com case) it seemed that something went wrong in the decision-making process
column4: because one of the main public partners (i.e.
column5: police) threatened to withdraw their support just a few hours before the launch of an action (Idem
column6: p.2). The reason for the police to react in this way is that they did not know whether this problem
column7: illegal hotel prostitution
column8: was a real problem at all; whether this was an appropriate role for them to take; how the public would respond to this action; and how the media would influence the future relationships between the police and the hotels (Idem
column9: p.2). This example shows that some fundamental dilemmas were not tackled during the decision-making process.

column1: (d) Any significant changes in the institutional architecture of collaboration over time
The institutional architecture of the collaboration did not significantly change over time. In all three cases there was a so-called ‘on-the-fly collaboration’
column2: which means that the groups were temporary
column3: fluid and diffuse and that various partners connected because of a shared interest. The reason for the public and private partners to join the collaboration was because of their shared interest in the fight against human trafficking.

- Philippine Sailors case: the process did not change so much over time.

column1: (c) The changes to collective outputs and social outcomes over time
Seven years after the start (2005-2011)
column2: the following results were realized. First
column3: the public and political awareness of the human trafficking problem has increased. This problem is not solely related to sexual exploitation
column4: but also to other forms of modern slavery (e.g.
column5: sailors
column6: au pairs
column7: agricultural workers) (Ibid
column8: p.9). Second
column9: the novel
column10: integrated approach has been institutionalized in a National Task Force on Human Trafficking in 2008. In this Task Force a variety of public partners work together in the fight against human trafficking practices (Ibid
column11: p.9). Third
column12: the number of reported victims has increased
column13: and the number of prosecutions has remained constant. In both cases
column14: it is unknown whether this is the result of the operations as described above (Ibid
column15: p.9). Ultimately
column16: the Dutch Public Prosecution Service has learned a lot about the victims
column17: perpetrators and enablers of trafficking
column18: and about collaborations with public and private partners and the role of media (p.10).

column2: CenterPoint (gas) and the city was due to be renewed in 2014.

column1: The campaign argued that a public option and local control could accelerate the renewable transition and make it accessible to all
column2: benefit the local economy
column3: and lower prices. The focus
column4: however
column5: was not on a specific model of utility design
column6: or even on municipalization as the only answer. Rather the campaign focused on the frame of exploring Minneapolis’ options during the concession process to know
column7: and broaden
column8: what was possible. So
column9: rather than coming with specific ways to democratize the internal operations of a utility
column10: they brought up these topics more generally in an effort to start a public conversation and see how they could shift that discussion by bringing up municipalization as a unique lever in this debate that would

column1: force action from utilities. They also wanted to strategically use the city as an actor to
push the introduction of commoning practices to the energy system more broadly.
Participants in the campaign were frustrated by the non-responsiveness of the utilities and their blocking of renewables and decentralized generation
column2: and their inefficient programs/progress to decarbonize or increase efficiency
column3: and to make this transition accessible to all. It was clear that the utilities were the main target to address Minneapolis' carbon emissions
column4: as they controlled at the time 2/3 of the city's emissions and their plans at the time anticipated reducing carbon intensity by only 3.6% by 2025.

column1: b) The goals of the campaign included: 1) City ownership and “shifting decision making” and power to a local
column2: accountable forum 2) Localized renewable energy and democratizing the energy system 3) Educating people about perverse incentives of the current utility model 4) Shifting economic benefit away from energy monopolies to the local economy 5) Using municipalization as a wedge to force action
column3: saying the city needed more options in its energy contracts

column1: c) The campaign was able to shift council opinion and build enough public and media pressure that council had to act to adopt a new approach with the investor owned utilities
column2: but they did not agree to put the initiative to authorize municipalization on the ballot. Instead
column3: after a period of study

column1: One important factor in this direction of events was a public hearing where the electric utility Xcel mobilized significant opposition from particularly the business community
column2: and the utilities’ organization of a significant and influential oppositional campaign. Another primary factor was a state law in Minnesota that required that in municipalization proceedings
column3: cities would have to consider lost profits to the utility
column4: which created much financial and legal doubt about the feasibility of going the municipalization route under those circumstances.

column1: ;3;5;Self-initiated by participants;4;5;Off;5;5;2;3;5;5;Off;Off;3;Highly confident;a) The vision and impetus of Minneapolis Energy Options came largely out of people who had been politicized in fighting against the utilities in various ways and times finding each other as they realized the importance of a window of opportunity around the renewal of franchise agreements. The campaign was started by a core group of around 7 people who started thinking of the idea separately at the same time. One sub-group knew each other through environmental justice work and more and less recent efforts to change the design and values of the energy utility system in Minnesota. Another sub group were more institutionally established within organizations doing climate
column2: as well as local economy work. Both reached out to the Green Party member of the Minneapolis City Council and his council aide
column3: and got connected to each other. The campaign was organized independently of city hall
column4: but having the support of a CM's office did make a significant difference throughout the campaign.

column1: b) This was in 2011 (Phase 1 2011-2012)
column2: and they decided to work together around an effort to urge the city and people of Minneapolis to consider what options they had in this time when the franchise agreements were coming up for renewal. They wanted to see a dramatic shift in many elements of the energy system
column3: and they quickly come to the conclusion that doing so through by bringing up municipalization was the strongest position. This conclusion was clear for a number of reasons. The most central was that municipalization was unique in its ability to strike fear into the utilities
column4: create leverage and force action and a larger discussion of what was needed.

column1: c) MEO organized a coalition of about 50 social movement organizations on paper
column2: but the size of the coalition and level of mobilization the campaign achieved was not extremely decentralized
column3: in part because of how the process for potential municipalization was structured. In this structure
column4: the city council would need to vote to put a question to authorize (looking into) municipalization on the ballot
column5: and so the campaign had to first and foremost convince the city council
column6: rather than the general public. The campaign focused on informing residents that there were other options in energy provision
column7: starting a public and political discussion about these topics
column8: and using various tactics to put pressure on the council
column9: including going through the party endorsement process for the ballot initiative
column10: and choosing to run their campaign during a municipal election year and having candidates take positions on it
column11: so that the issue would be front and center in campaigning and election discussions. The high point of the campaign was 2013 (Phase 2).

column1: Some impactful framing conditions for the campaign included: 1) a certain dynamic of catch 22  around the state law language: the city would only have standing to do a formal feasibility study with cost estimates once they had voter approval to authorize municipalization. But opponents of municipalization often liked to use this lack of cost information as the city not knowing the implications of the path they were embarking on
column2: or on the other hand a vote to authorize municipalization locking the city into that path. For this and other reasons the campaign argued that getting authorization was about having the option to go down the municipalization path if it proved the best option. 2) There was another existing law that became a major factor in the campaign: the so-called “poison pill.” Minnesota state law around municipalization included a provision that the electric utility successfully advocated for in the 1970s that mandates that in municipalization proceedings
column3: lost profits to the utility must be a factor in determining the buying price the city must pay
column4: even in the eminent domain route. This law ended up being a primary reason why the council was hesitant about the municipalization route
column5: because costs
column6: including legal costs
column7: might turn out to be prohibitive.

column4: a group of about fifteen - twenty or so people who met weekly and made decisions in that circle. There were definitely more active volunteers and people who showed up to events (~100 active

column6: and 2 council representatives

column1: The goals of CEP were formulated through a new Energy Vision document that came as a response to the campaign
column2: which included energy equity and reducing disparities as prime goals. These stacked upon the already formulated goal of Minneapolis' Climate Action Plan which was finalized earlier in 2013. The partnership was formed around Memorandums of Understandings the city signed with each utility
column3: along with new (shorter) franchise agreements
column4: and work plans that were formed out of that that lasted for 2 or later for 3 years. The campaign had background influence on the content of the MOU priorities but the first years were more just about getting the partnership up and running and a lot of analysis and mapping in all sectors. Utilities reported progress on energy reductions from and participation in their legally mandated energy efficiency programs
column5: and the first more involved board level discussion (end of its first year
column6: 2015) was on establishing metrics for the partnership work.

column1: The areas of work were categorized under: Greenhouse Gas Emissions (community wide and municipal use); Energy use (residential and commercial/industrial); Renewable electricity (community wide
column2: municipal use
column3: and proportion local/direct purchased). Earlier plans concentrated more exclusively on a breakdown of various types of buildings for efficiency programs (more or less the city helping the utilities on their mandated goals) along with municipal operations. Later items were added on workforce development
column4: and on inclusive financing (an on-bill option that allows low-income people and renters the ability to pay for energy efficiency upgrades from their savings

column6: which however were reported to take up an inordinate amount of its work and staff time to complete.
